title: Getting Started: Navigating the Student Dashboard
body:
Quill student accounts have an easy-to-navigate dashboard that allows students to access all of their assigned activities, keep track of their assignments, and gauge their concept proficiency.

Once students log in to their Quill accounts, the first page they see is the **Classes** page. This page houses all of the classes to which they belong. To enter a class, the student clicks on that class's card.

![https://downloads.intercomcdn.com/i/o/193870553/c326e1f7692a37ba1d5ea302/Screen+Shot+2020-03-19+at+5.19.13+PM.png](https://downloads.intercomcdn.com/i/o/193870553/c326e1f7692a37ba1d5ea302/Screen+Shot+2020-03-19+at+5.19.13+PM.png)

Once a student has entered a class, they are brought to the **Classwork** page. The **Classwork** view has three tabs: **All Activities**, **To-do Activities**, and **Completed Activities**.

Under **All Activities,** students can browse and access all of their assigned activities on Quill—both completed and not completed.  All activity packs are listed in the order that they are assigned by the teacher; more recently assigned activities will appear at the top.

![https://downloads.intercomcdn.com/i/o/193870959/49d18d35c111f29544d2d011/Quill+org+++Classwork.png](https://downloads.intercomcdn.com/i/o/193870959/49d18d35c111f29544d2d011/Quill+org+++Classwork.png)

Under the **To-Do Activities** section, students can start new activities, see the tool type for each assigned activity, and access the due date for each activity.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_org_Classwork__1_.png)

Under the **Completed Activities** section, students can access their score range for each completed activity. They also have the option to [replay activities.](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-encourage-replay-for-improved-recall)

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_org_Classwork__2_.png)

Students can view the completion status of their activities under any of the student dashboard sections. If the activity is marked "Start," the student has not yet begun the activity. If it is marked "Resume," the student has started the activity, but not yet completed it. Under any of these views, if it is marked "Replay," the student has successfully completed and submitted the activity and now has the opportunity to replay and improve their score. If an activity is marked "Completed," the activity has been completed, but there is not the opportunity for replay.

title: How does Quill decide which grammar rules to teach?
body:
Quill follows the guidelines for grammar and style published in the *[Chicago Manual of Style](https://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/home.html)*. While other style guides are geared towards specific audiences and genres of writing, the *Chicago Manual of Style* is designed to support writers of all types, making it the best-suited and most [mission-aligned](https://www.quill.org/about) guide for Quill. Quill enforces rules not otherwise enforced by other style guides such as the oxford comma, using "since" as both a conjunction of time and a conjunction of cause and effect, and no dangling participles. If questions arise about a concept or a rule and Quill's content creators cannot find answers in the Chicago Manual, then we do in-depth research of credible sources on the concept—exploring grammarians’ explanations and perspectives, referencing published works on grammar, and more— and draw conclusions from these sources. We never use public forums or uncredited sites to inform our decisions; all of the sources that we use are research-backed.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/864px-The_Chicago_Manual_of_Style__Seventeenth_Edition.jpg)

When Quill first began building its library, we focused on building a foundational cohort of activities aligned to Common Core Writing Standards. We are constantly adding new content to accommodate shifting standards and uncovered content areas:

1. What are the most common issues in student writing? What are the areas that students consistently struggle in, even after direct instruction? What are the basics that high school students, for example, still haven’t quite mastered?

2. What are teachers asking for? What is challenging for them to teach? What topics do teachers spend the most time on in the classroom because they are a priority?

3. What skills do students need to have in order to eventually write at a level that helps them succeed in college and, more importantly, that are essential for engaging with the world and current political, social, and economic conversations?

4. What are the gaps in our current offering (with the goal to offer a complete writing/grammar curriculum)? Which areas that are important to students and teachers are not covered by other tools?

Currently, Quill looks to address the following questions when adding new content. These questions are informed by the needs and feedback of Quill teachers, as well as the methodologies of expert grammarians.

In addition to these practices, Quill takes it very seriously when teachers reach out to us asking for new rules or suggesting that we may have gotten a rule wrong. We are committed to always delving into the content in question. While maintaining the integrity of technical grammar, Quill is very open to changing our guidelines as rules change, ideas change, and the English language changes.

title: How does Quill address learning for At-Risk (Below Grade Level) Learners?
body:
Quill is committed to supporting learners at all levels. While Quill aligns its activities to Common Core Standards, teachers can assign activities of any level to their students regardless of each learner's current grade level. Read on to learn the four main ways that Quill supports at-risk (below grade level) learners.

**1) Quill has a series of diagnostic assessments designed to meet students where they are.**

 Quill offers [five different diagnostic assessments](http://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-tools-overview-of-quills-5-diagnostics) to determine each student's conceptual understanding and identify learning gaps. While Quill's diagnostics cover progressively more complex concepts, they are not aligned to any grade levels. Instead, they are entirely skill-based. This allows below grade-level learners to get the differentiated practice they need to get on grade level, while at grade-level learners work on grade-level content.

After students complete a diagnostic assessment, Quill uses the results to recommend practice activities specific to concepts the student did not fully understand. Each student can then follow a personalized practice track, working on mastering one concept at a time.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Diag_Recs.png)

**Working with at-risk learners tip #1:** Regardless of the grade level that you teach, start by assigning all ELA students the Starter Diagnostic and all ELL students the ELL Starter Diagnostic. This will ensure that no skills are falling through the cracks for any students.

**Working with at-risk learners tip #2:** [Pace the assignment of recommended activity packs](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-pacing-the-assignment-of-diagnostic-recommendations) to help students focus on mastering one concept at a time.

**2) Teachers can assign individual activities to individual students within their classes, allowing them to give students appropriately challenging tasks.**

On Quill, teachers can [build their own customized activity pack](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049954-how-do-i-create-and-assign-a-new-activity-pack) and [assign it to individual students or groups of students within a class](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1060361-can-i-assign-an-activity-pack-or-diagnostic-assessment-to-only-some-students-in-my-classroom-but-not-the-entire-group). Teachers can browse through our library of over 600 activities and filter through by tool type, common core standard, or concept and assign specially-made packs to at-risk learners, helping them get up to grade-level.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-06-18_at_12.04.44_PM.png)

**Working with at-risk learners tip #3:** [This article](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/getting-the-most-out-of-your-customized-activity-packs) outlines how to maximize learning with customized activity packs, regardless of student level.

**3) Quill uses a [mastery-based learning](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-and-masterybased-learning) model to encourage skill acquisition at a student's own pace**

Mastery-based learning (also known as proficiency-based, standards-based, or competency-based learning) is an approach to instruction that requires students to demonstrate a clear understanding of a topic or concept before progressing to a new topic or concept. This approach inherently acknowledges that different students will need different levels of practice and intervention in order to reach mastery of a particular concept.

Quill's tools make it easy to support a mastery-based learning classroom. In addition to the practice methods outlined above, Quill provides in-depth student data reports to show instantaneous progress and proficiency tracking. To learn more about how different Quill features can support mastery-based learning, [check out this article.](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-and-masterybased-learning)

**4) Quill's Lessons tool allows teachers to provide direct instruction for students in need of remediation in a particular concept**

[Quill Lessons](https://www.quill.org/tools/lessons) is a powerful tool that teachers can use to introduce or review grammar concepts with their students in an interactive and collaborative way. Throughout the Lesson, there are many opportunities for engagement and differentiation. If teachers are using a Lesson to introduce a concept to their class, they can flag the students that are having a hard time grasping the concept and follow up with those students individually or in small groups following the Lesson. If teachers are using the Lesson to review concepts with individual students or small groups, they can slow down the process and ensure that each student's needs are met.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2018-07-25_at_5.00.44_PM.png)

Meeting students where they are, whether it's at, below, or above grade level, is the key to helping students become confident writers. Quill is committed to helping students build confidence, learn at their own pace, and become strong writers.

title: Quill.org's Resources for Teachers and Parents Impacted by Emergency School Closures
body:
**Are you a teacher or parent looking to help your students or children improve their writing skills through online learning tools?** Quill.org is here to help! We provide more than 600 free activities that help students become strong writers. As students work through Quill activities, we provide immediate feedback so that students can effectively revise their work and quickly build their writing skills. To get started, we provide diagnostic assessments so that you can see which skills your kids should practice and then with one click, you can assign those practice activities. It's easy! **Parents, guardians, and families, Quill is 100% free for everyone, not just teachers. Just sign up as an educator, and then add your child or children as students to your class.** Quill’s nonprofit mission is to provide free learning tools and materials for all students, teachers, and families. In addition to our free tools, we wanted to let you know about some other ways we will support you during this crisis.
---
## **1. Free Quill Premium for all Educators (Teachers and Parents!)** Effective March 18, 2020, all educators (teachers, parents, and guardians) will have free access to Quill Premium for Teachers. To get access, just click on the link below and we will immediately activate Teacher Premium and the free subscription will be active through July 2020. Activate Free Quill Premium for Teachers Quill Premium for Teachers provides you with additional reports to better understand how your students are progressing, as well as the ability to download and export reports as PDFs or CSV files so that you can share this data with other educators, administrators, and parents.
[Learn more about Quill Premium for Teachers.](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1068118-what-do-i-get-with-a-premium-subscription) **District administrators**, we are also granting district-wide Quill Premium. Your entire district will be able to use Quill Premium and access additional reports. To request district-wide Premium, please complete this form and a member of our team will follow up with you.
[Free Quill Premium for Districts Request Form](https://forms.gle/ePA3C866hfKkN6BRA)

---
## **2. Best Practices for Using Quill in a Remote Learning Environment** To get started with Quill, we have curated a set of resources for effectively using Quill. These guides and videos can help you get started on Quill and then follow the progress as your students and children develop their writing skills. **Remote learning instructional tips**
[Best Practices for Teachers using Quill for Remote Learning](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/4-tips-to-maximize-remote-learning-with-quill)
[Best Practice Tips for Parents using Quill at Home](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/using-quill-as-a-homeschool-educator) ---
**Quick tutorials: five easy steps to get started on Quill**
*It takes less than 5 minutes to sign up, set up, and get to learning!*
**Step One:** [Sign Up](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049949-how-do-i-sign-up-as-a-teacher)
**Step Two:** [Create a Class](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049937-how-do-i-create-classes)
**Step Three:** [Add Students](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049939-how-do-i-invite-add-students-to-my-classes)
**Step Four:** Start by [Assigning the Diagnostic](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049933-how-do-i-assign-a-quill-diagnostic) and then [Assign Recommended Learning Activities](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589522-how-do-i-assign-diagnostic-recommendations) once students complete the diagnostic.
**Step Five:** *(Optional)* [Select and Assign Additional Activities](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049954-how-do-i-create-and-assign-a-new-activity-pack)

**Leveraging Quill's Data Reports**
*Quill provides valuable insight into student writing performance, no matter where you or your students are. Check out our 6 high-impact reports:* **Always Available:**
[Activity Summary](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work)
[Activity Analysis](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589337-how-do-i-read-the-activity-analysis)
[Diagnostic Report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589441-how-do-i-read-the-diagnostics-report)
**Provided with Free Premium:**
[Activity Scores Report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1650560-how-do-i-read-the-activity-scores-report)
[Concepts Report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049943-how-do-i-read-the-concepts-premium-reports)
[Standards Report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049953-how-do-i-read-the-standards-premium-reports)
---
## **3. Live Webinars** **Webinar 201: Diving into Data** Tuesday, May 26 from 2-3pm Registration: [Click here to pre-register!](https://quill-4d8f261b98ec.intercom-clicks.com/via/e?ob=2whzJuHNmyLmN7CEkxMjDOrEIkz86YgQ0ot5yHmqSivQidTnwlEEFVp954mkA3rUSOQqbeqqIDTG7GTj6KQ5mQ%3D%3D&h=71dcdb803c6c80f63f2ad816ae03b8363b5653cf-v2ms5bl3_26995778887) **Webinar 301: Diving into Instruction** Thursday, May 21 & Thursday, May 28 from 2-3pm Registration: [Click here to pre-register!](https://quill-4d8f261b98ec.intercom-clicks.com/via/e?ob=fVaiw4DeZY%2Fs1QfYzQO84ie5ytKNcP8UTnA5lLpHR6ZWNEE%2FKMK1slKzpDNcSipK8dHv6vmK2g10xxjIMDxTNA%3D%3D&h=ec3c723992a72a577134a3a94509b261ed79944c-v2ms5bl3_26995778887) **Webinar 101: Getting Started with Quill** is not being offered live right now, but you can watch a recording of it [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R4pOnC9NMDE&feature=youtu.be) ---
## **Questions? We're here to help!** Feel free to reach out anytime:
Our support page: [support.quill.org](https://support.quill.org)
Email us at: [support@quill.org](mailto:support@quill.org)

title: Tiny Tips for Teachers: Quill & Helping Students Type Well
body:
Quill activities help students improve general typing skills by focusing on correct spelling, punctuation, capitalization, and spacing. A majority of Quill's activities focus on sentence-level writing; however, a certain level of typing proficiency is required to complete them. If students are still developing their typing skills, don't worry! Here are a few tips for using Quill with students of varying typing skills.

### For lower-proficiency typists

- **Do Quill activities as a group**

Any of Quill's independent practice activities can be completed as a group using a projector or SmartBoard. Teachers stand at the board and facilitate the grammar activity by projecting each question and having students write down their answers, either individually or collaboratively, on a sheet of paper. Teachers can then call on students to share their responses and type their responses into Quill on behalf of their students.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/fullsizeoutput_19c8__1_.jpeg)

- **Use Quill in a station rotation session around typing**

In this station rotation session, explicitly combine typing practice with grammar instruction. In this rotation, set up one station for isolated typing practice on free apps like [TypingClub](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/typingclub/obdbgibnhfcjmmpfijkpcihjieedpfah?hl=en) or [Typing Test - KeyHero](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/typing-test-keyhero/jkcieoaeooeidmpaopkpjpjfakidlabm?hl=en), one station for practicing typing on Quill, and one station in which students type their own sentences using a specific grammar concept.

### For growing typists

- **Use extensions**

When students first begin working independently on Quill for the first time, use [chrome extensions](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1058670-free-extensions-for-students-with-modifications-iep-ell) to support students with activity completion. While some of these extensions do not focus explicitly on typing skills, they can support students with activity completion and general practice.

- **Start independent work with [Quill Grammar activities](https://www.quill.org/tools/grammar)**

Start growing typists on their independent Quill journies by assigning [Quill Grammar activities](https://www.quill.org/tools/grammar). Quill Grammar activities tend to have shorter prompts that require less typing, but they still provide high-quality grammar practice for fundamental concepts.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-06-03_at_3.05.02_PM.png)

### **For skilled typists**

- **Use [Quill Connect activities](https://www.quill.org/tools/connect) to take practice to the next level**

When students have gained higher typing proficiency, they are ready to move onto [Quill Connect activities](https://www.quill.org/tools/connect)! Quill Connect activities ask students to combine simple sentences to make more complex sentences. These activities typically require that students type slightly longer and more nuanced sentences and employ a variety of punctuation keys.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-06-03_at_3.06.38_PM.png)

- **Start long-form skill transfer typing work**

Students can continue to practice their typing skills while honing their grammar proficiency. After students complete a Quill activity, challenge them to type a short paragraph using the grammar concept that they just practiced on Quill.

### Bonus tip for teaching typists of any skill level!

- Encourage students to pay attention to typing! You can offer students extra credit for catching a typo in a teacher-created document, or a published text

The more automatic typing becomes for your students, the more students can focus their cognitive energy on *what* they are writing rather than *how* they are writing, allowing them to write with more nuance and sophistication.

title: Introducing Quill's Weekly Webinar Series!
body:
Quill's instructional coaches have prepared three distinct webinars to support Quill teachers of all experience levels. Each 60-minute webinar will begin with a live presentation, followed by an interactive question-and-answer session. This webinar series will run weekly throughout the month of May.  See below for the schedule and registration details!

### **Webinar 101: Getting Started with Quill**

- **Description**: For teachers new to Quill (or in need of a refresher), this webinar will cover how to set up classes, a demo of Quill's five different learning tools, and how to assign activities.
- **Schedule**: Each **Monday** in May from **2:00pm-3:00pm EDT**
*(May 4th, 11th, 18th)*
- **Registration**: [Click here to select your desired date and pre-register for Webinar 101!](https://zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_RiGS-BOtSxyArdJtoPdtrQ)

### **Webinar 201: Diving into Data**

- **Description**: For teachers of any Quill experience level, this webinar will review how to interpret and utilize each of Quill's seven student data reports.
- **Schedule**: Each **Tuesday** in May from **2:00pm-3:00pm EDT**
*(May 5th, 12th, 19th, 26th)*
- **Registration**: [Click here to select your desired date and pre-register for Webinar 201!](https://zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_lF7bauoERjmFER-bfds2wQ)

### **Webinar 301: Diving into Instruction**

- **Description**: For teachers familiar with Quill, this webinar will discuss strategies to embed Quill into your current daily or weekly instructional plans.
- **Schedule**: Each **Thursday** in May from **2:00pm-3:00pm EDT**
*(May 7th, 14th, 21st, 28th)*
- **Registration**: [Click here to select your desired date and pre-register for Webinar 301!](https://zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_DuEYB-0xQ-WaL7mXJLFmFA)
subtitle: Join Quill's instructional coaches for a series of webinars presented live throughout the month of May.

title: Using Quill to Support Mastery-Based Learning
body:
**Mastery-based learning** (also known as proficiency-based, standards-based, or competency-based learning) is an approach to instruction that requires students to demonstrate a clear understanding of a topic or concept before progressing to a new topic or concept. This approach inherently acknowledges that different students will need more or less practice and a varied amount of time to demonstrate mastery of a particular concept. Creating and maintaining a mastery-based classroom requires flexible planning and constant analysis of student progress data. For more background on mastery-based learning, check out [Edmentum's clear description and implementation strategies](https://www.edmentuminternational.com/blog/understanding-mastery-based-learning/), as well as a [case study of the approach in a New York City middle school.](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/11/nyregion/mastery-based-learning-no-grades.html)

Quill's tools make it easy to support a mastery-based learning classroom. Quill's diagnostic assessments are built to identify skill gaps among each student, all Quill activities are aligned to particular concepts and standards, and the student data reports provide instantaneous progress and proficiency tracking. Read on to learn about how different Quill features can help make this potentially daunting approach manageable for you and meaningful to your students.

###  **Use Diagnostic Recommendations to Create Individualized Learning Plans**

Use one of Quill's [five diagnostic assessments](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-tools-overview-of-quills-5-diagnostics) to determine each student's conceptual understanding and identify gaps. After students complete the assessment, Quill uses the results to recommend practice activities specific to concepts the student did not fully understand. Each student can then follow a personalized practice track, working on mastering one concept at a time.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Diag_Recs.png)

**Mastery Tip #1**: [Pace the assignment of recommended activity packs](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-pacing-the-assignment-of-diagnostic-recommendations) to help students focus on mastering one concept at a time.

**Mastery Tip #2**: Use the [Activity Summary report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work) and filter by current activity pack to track your students' progress and proficiency in on concept before assigning the next recommendation.

### **Use Due Dates to Provide Students a Replay Window to "Go for Green"**

Students can replay any of Quill's independent learning activities (Connect, Grammar, and Proofreader) as many times as they need to fully understand the activity's featured skill. When a student replays an activity, it will not look exactly the same as the first time—new questions will be filtered in and remaining questions reordered. You can give students a "replay window" by [designated due dates](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1065187-how-can-i-assign-activities-in-a-specific-order) for assignments or entire activity packs. Encourage students to "go for green" and replay the activities as needed during this timeframe - allowing students to take several at-bats at understanding the concepts.

The student below is working on mastering her use of prepositions. Her teacher has given her until the listed date to replay her activities to "go for green" and achieve proficiency across the concept.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Replay_-_Maya_Prepositions.png)

**Mastery Tip #3:** You can view and track your students' replay attempts using the Activity Summary report. Replayed activities will be counted and designated by a small blue number at the top right corner of the activity square. Hover over the activity square to see the score for each replay. The activity square color will reflect the highest level of proficiency achieved across all replay attempts.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Act_Sum_Replay_2.png)

### **Make Mastery-Based Instructional Pivots**

One of the challenges of instituting mastery-based learning is pivoting your instructional plans to remediate students who are still mastering a concept while moving forward with others. If the Activity Summary report shows a student is struggling with a particular concept after replaying activities, consider one or more of these strategies:

- **Hold Regularly Scheduled Remediation Sessions** - Dedicate a regular time each week (or cadence of your choice) to hold a concept remediation session, e.g., 30 minutes at the end of one class each week or as a standing video conference. (You can jazz up the name so it is memorable and meaningful to students like "Preposition Power Hour" or "Mastery Mondays"). These can be invite-only for students who need further support to master the session's target concept.
- **Use Quill Lessons to Reteach a Concept** - During your scheduled concept remediation sessions, you can use a corresponding [Quill Lesson](https://www.quill.org/tools/lessons) to provide an interactive deep dive. Quill Lessons allow for group discussion about the rules and usage of a particular grammar concept, in-the-moment practice examples, and flagging of students who need additional follow-up. If your class is currently in a distance-learning setting, [here are tips for using Quill Lessons remotely](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-using-quill-lessons-as-a-remote-resource).
- **Student-Master Tutoring** - When a student masters a new concept, they can become a tutor to another student who is still deepening their understanding. Task the tutor with developing their own prompts modeled after the relevant Quill activity and to work with their tutee to complete. Achieving tutor status can become part of a classwide incentive program.

### **Keep Previously Mastered Skills Sharp**

A major reservation of those new to mastery-based learning is that as students move from one skill to the next, they can quickly forget previously-learned content. It's important to find sticky ways to revisit those mastered concepts. Here are a few ideas to try:

- **Schedule Replay Days** - Regularly dedicate class time for students to replay activities from their mastered concepts. Replaying those activities will strengthen students' ability to recall and utilize information stored in their memory banks. [Read much more about the act of replay to improve content recall here](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-encourage-replay-for-improved-recall).
- **Assign Quill Proofreader Activities** - [Quill Proofreader](https://www.quill.org/tools/proofreader) activities are often not included in diagnostic recommendation activity packs and remain available to assign as additional practice—giving students a new way to demonstrate their knowledge in the context of a pre-written passage. Filter for the Proofreader tool in Quill's Activity Library and then search through the available concepts.
![](hhttp://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Proofreader_Ex.png)

- **Use Mastery Editing Checklists -** The goal of Quill is to ultimately improve students' authentic writing across all settings. Students can generate their own editing guides with a checklist of mastered skills to review in their writing pieces. For a step further, students can also note an example sentence of the concept in use.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Editing_Checklist.png)

### **Ideas for Mastery-Based Grading with Quill**

Mastery-based learning assesses students on progress and growth over time, which can prove challenging to capture in a traditional grade book. Consider these options for using Quill data reports for mastery-based grading:

- **Activity-Specific Grades** - Use the [Activity Scores report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1650560-how-do-i-read-the-activity-scores-report) to gather percentage scores for each activity a student completes at the end of your replay window. As a student replays an activity, the **highest** score will be reflected in the Activity Scores report.
- **Concept-Specific Grades** - The Activity Scores report also delivers an average percentage score for each activity pack, which can align to a concept percentage score as well. This score will also recalculate as students replay activities for mastery. Below is a snapshot of a student's Activity Scores report for the *Prepositions and Prepositional Phrases* activity pack. If "preposition mastery" were a column in your grade book, this student is currently earning 86% based on their activity completion and replay attempts to date.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Average_Activity_Score.png)

- **Learn more!** - [Read more about the practice and impact of mastery-based grading in this excerpt from *Leaders of Their Own Learning* in EL Education's Resource Library.](https://eleducation.org/resources/chapter-8-standards-based-grading#)

title: Edtech and Social Listening
body:
*“No one is as deaf as the man who does not listen” (proverb).*

**[Gartner,](http://www.gartner.com/newsroom/id/3225717)** a tech advisory firm, highlighted “social listening” as one of the top ten strategic technologies for education in 2016. Working in an edtech startup, I have learned to appreciate the power of social listening.

# Social Mentions: Social WEdia
In the case of Quill, most social mentions I found came from **[Twitter](https://twitter.com/quill_org)** and **[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/quill.org/)**. Every morning, the mentions by teachers were one of the most inspiring things. By looking at the hashtags (#) and other names mentioned (@) in the posts, I had a better idea of what topics were popular among the teachers, and who were prominent or rising players in the education space.

When we use social media, too often we focus on promoting ourselves rather than listening to other people. However, what matters is to have two-way communication with other people in the community. Quill believes in social WEdia, rather than social MEdia, where we use social media platforms to ask questions and listen to others. Listening to teachers on social media is a way to communicate with them on a very personal level. By talking to teachers, we create a shared understanding of how to serve students. To extend Quill’s social WEdia, Quill can hold online social events, such as Twitter chats or Facebook Live events.

# Inbound Links: Competitive Understanding
Quill uses Moz to track all of the inbound links. Inbound links are not only great for SEO, they also enable us to see what educators are saying about us. By checking the inbound links, I could define the direct and indirect competitors of Quill, and build a perceptual map of the competitive landscape. By checking the inbound links, I found out that Quill had been mentioned in a Harvard educational review. By checking the inbound links, I was able to build a list of influencers to reach out to. Every link is an opportunity.

# Analytics: The Data Talk
Telling the stories out of the data is a challenging yet exciting job. Analytics tools, such as Google Analytics, Google Adwords, and Google Trend, can help us analyze our visitors and our competitors’ visitors. After this analytical process, I came up with recommendations on targeted channels and geographical areas, potential keywords for more conversion, and ideas for a better user experience.

# CRM: The Human Talk
Helping teachers on Intercom, I learned more about the functions of the products, the challenges of the teachers, and the impact of the whole initiative. These conversations inspired me to contact some teachers to hear their stories, resulting in the articles **“[Creating a “Wow” Class With Technology](https://medium.com/@quill/how-i-created-more-tech-savvy-activities-for-a-wow-class-ee9c99b02d65#.d6lrasvdb)”** and **”[Filling in the Gap in Education](https://medium.com/@quill/quill-helps-fill-in-a-size-able-gap-5d098cb19f04#.b2emnz5jv).”** These conversations with teachers also gave us new ideas on creating helpful content, such as the instructional videos to help teachers navigate the site.

I also learned from Peter and Hannah how to use Quill’s CRM system. I was very impressed to see that Peter asked a teacher on Intercom about the Youtube channel in her email signature, which showed that he truly cared and wanted to develop a customer relationship, not just a transactional interaction.

title: The Challenges of Creating Combined Activity Packs
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_logo_white_large.png)

Quill has over 20 activity packs and over 200 additional activities available to teachers. The activities range in topic, grade level, and amount of instruction. In the activity packs, the students ideally can practice concepts one by one before moving on to less guided activities. In writing these more involved activities, there are several challenges the content developer faces.

## Using combined activity packs
The* and, or, but, so* combined activity pack aims to test students in a way that closely mimics real-life writing, in which there are no cues. The activity pack used, based on many facts about bats, was yielding answers that indicated student confusion. The activity pack was revised to still include all four joining word options, but with sentences that have one clear best option.

The *and, or, but, so* combined activity pack aims to test students in a way that closely mimics real-life writing, in which there are no cues. The activity pack used, based on many facts about bats, was yielding answers that indicated student confusion. The activity pack was revised to still include all four joining word options, but with sentences that have one clear best option.

## Finding sentences exclusive to *and*
One issue with the questions is that students were using and to connect sentences that were intended to have a different joining word. For example:

Bats live in caves. They sleep upside down.

The question was written with the intended answer of “Bats live in caves, and they sleep upside down.” However, it was not clear to students if there is a causal or opposing relationship between the two sentences, or no relationship. Also, some students may combine the two using a compound predicate. Both these issues were resolved with a new prompt:

There are over 1000 species of bats. Many eat insects.

By using two subjects and two unrelated facts about bats, it is clearer that and is the best joining word to use, making the answer “There are over 1000 species of bats, and many eat insects.”

## Clear causal relationships
The need to make causal relationships more obvious was also addressed. Sometimes adding minimal words can create a clearer relationship. For example:

Bats eat mosquitos. Bats are useful.

One word was added, changing the first sentence to “Bats eat pesky mosquitos,” to indicate that by eating mosquitoes, bats are getting rid of a nuisance, which makes them useful.

The Challenges of Creating Combined Activity Packs

title: Quill's Implementation Library
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Remote-Learning-Resources.png)

Quill has 5 different tools and over 600 activities to help students become strong writers. With a library this large, the implementation possibilities are endless! Many teachers mix and match implementation methods to find a strategy that perfectly suits their needs. Please note that, no matter how you choose to implement Quill, we recommend that students use our tools 3-5 times a week in 10 to 15-minute bursts. Read on to learn about common implementation strategies and best practice tips for using Quill with your students.

**Use Quill as a warm-up or cool down:** Using Quill for 10-15 minutes, 3-5 times a week at the beginning or end of class can help students rapidly strengthen their writing skills. Here are some articles detailing how to maximize this time with your students:

[Teacher Toolbox: Setting Up Remote Routines with Quill](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/teacher-toolbox-setting-up-remote-routines-with-quill)

[Best Practices: How to use Quill when you don't have time for the diagnostic](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-to-use-quill-when-you-dont-have-time-for-the-diagnostic)

[Best Practices: How to Support Students During Independent Practice](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-can-supporting-students-during-independent-practice)

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: Pacing the Assignment of Diagnostic Recommendations](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-pacing-the-assignment-of-diagnostic-recommendations)

*Teacher Stories:*

[Michele Ellis uses Quill to Facilitate a Dialogue with her 7th Grade Language Arts Class](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/michele-ellis-teacher-story)

[Jennifer Beasley uses Quill to Increase Digital Agility in the Classroom](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/meeting-students-where-they-are--jennifer-beasley-8th-grade-ela-teacher)

[Kaysi Adams uses Quill to Encourage Student Ownership](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/student-ownership--kaysi-adams-5th-grade-writing-teacher)

**Use Quill in station rotations:** If you have a limited number of devices available to your students, if you're hoping to target a specific skill, or if you're looking to add some variety to your instruction and practice time, station rotations are a great solution!  Most teachers set up stations once per week. Check out the following articles and teacher stories to learn more about working Quill into station rotations:

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: Quill & Helping Students Type Well](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-quill--helping-students-type-well)

[Best Practices: How to Support Students During Independent Practice](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-can-supporting-students-during-independent-practice)

[Using Quill with Limited Access to Computers](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/using-quill-with-limited-access-to-computers)

*Teacher stories:*

[Rose Caruso Uses Quill to Provide Structure and Variety for her Seneca College Students](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/structure-and-variety--rose-caruso-secondary-education-teacher)

**Use Quill as a whole-class instructional tool:**  Quill has the tools and the functionality to support group learning. Our Quill Lessons tools is designed specifically for group instruction, and our independent practice tools also translate well to a full-class setting. Here are some suggestions for implementing Quill as a whole-class instructional tool:

[Four Ways to use Quill Lessons](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/4-ways-to-use-quill-lessons)

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: Quill & Helping Students Type Well](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-quill--helping-students-type-well)

[Using Quill to Support Mastery-Based Learning](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-and-masterybased-learning)

[Best Practices: How to use Quill when you don't have time for the diagnostic](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-to-use-quill-when-you-dont-have-time-for-the-diagnostic)

(Video) [Using Quill Lessons Remotely](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Using_Lessons_Remotely.mp4)

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: Using Quill Lessons as a Remote Resource](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-using-quill-lessons-as-a-remote-resource)

[Using Quill with Limited Access to Computers](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/using-quill-with-limited-access-to-computers)

*Teacher Stories:*

[Court Caywood Uses Scaffolded Quill Lessons to Strengthen her 6th Grader's Language Arts Skills](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/scaffolding--court-caywood-6th-grade-language-arts-teacher)

[Lynn Barringer is Taking the Terror out of Grammar for his 5th Grade English Class](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/taking-the-terror-out-of-grammar)

**Use Quill in small groups:** Whether you've identified a group of students that struggle with the same concept, you have a limited number of devices, or you're looking to generate more discussion, Quill's activities can be used in pairs and in small groups. Take a look at these tips and implementation strategies:

[Using Quill with Limited Access to Computers](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/using-quill-with-limited-access-to-computers)

[Four Ways to use Quill Lessons](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/4-ways-to-use-quill-lessons)

[Using Quill to Support Mastery-Based Learning](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-and-masterybased-learning)

[Best Practices: How to use Quill when you don't have time for the diagnostic](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-to-use-quill-when-you-dont-have-time-for-the-diagnostic)

**Schedule time for replay:** Quill supports a Mastery-Based Learning model and allows students to replay activities and work up to a proficient score. We recommend building time into your Quill schedule to allow students to practice and replay activities that they have previously completed. Here are some tips, tricks, and suggestions for replay sessions:

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: Encourage Replay for Improved Recall](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-encourage-replay-for-improved-recall)

[Quill for the Summer](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_for_the_Summer.pdf)

*Teacher Stories*

[Lynn Barringer is Taking the Terror out of Grammar for his 5th Grade English Class](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/taking-the-terror-out-of-grammar)

[Using Quill to Support Mastery-Based Learning](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-and-masterybased-learning)

[Best Practices: How to Support Students During Independent Practice](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-can-supporting-students-during-independent-practice)

**Create explicit skill transfer activities:** Writing practice means nothing for students if their skills do not transfer to their long-form writing. Quill encourages teachers to implement some skill transfer practice into their Quill time to keep writing skills sharp. Students can practice Quill sentences out loud, keep a Quill Skill Tracker journal, proofread their work for Quill skills, and more! Here are a few resources to guide you through encouraging skill transfer:

[Teacher Toolbox: Setting Up Remote Routines with Quill](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/teacher-toolbox-setting-up-remote-routines-with-quill)

[Family Toolbox: Creating a Culture of Writing at Home](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/family-toolbox-creating-a-culture-of-writing-at-home)

[Quill for the Summer](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_for_the_Summer.pdf)

[Best Practices: How to use Quill to teach ELL students](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-to-use-quill-to-teach-ell-students)

*Teacher Stories*

[Lynn Barringer is Taking the Terror out of Grammar for his 5th Grade English Class](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/taking-the-terror-out-of-grammar)

**Use Quill as homework:** If students have device access at home, Quill activities are the perfect homework assignment to ensure that students retain class concepts! Use class time to review concepts that students had a hard time with while working on Quill at home. Read on to learn more about using Quill in a home setting:

[Teacher Toolbox: Setting Up Remote Routines with Quill](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/teacher-toolbox-setting-up-remote-routines-with-quill)

[Using Quill as a Homeschool Educator](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/using-quill-as-a-homeschool-educator)

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: Encourage Replay for Improved Recall](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-encourage-replay-for-improved-recall)

**Use Quill as direct supplemental intervention:** In some instances, you may need to vary from your normal Quill routine and provide as-needed intervention to adequately support your students. Here are some recommendations on how you can support students who need immediate supplemental practice.

[Using Quill to Support Mastery-Based Learning](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-and-masterybased-learning)

[Best Practices: How to use Quill when you don't have time for the diagnostic](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/best-practices-how-to-use-quill-when-you-dont-have-time-for-the-diagnostic)

[Using Quill with Students with IEPs](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/using-quill-with-students-with-ieps)

T*eacher Stories:*

[ELA Writing Teacher Denise Glenn Uses Quill to Encourage Students to #LoveYourLearning](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/loveyourlearning--denise-glenn-ela-writing-teacher)

**Use Quill as a remote learning resource:** If you find yourself in a remote learning situation with your students, you can still use Quill to provide effective practice and instruction. We encourage teachers to set up deliberate remote routines and continue to use Quill's full-class resources while remote. The following resources will guide you through our recommendations:

[Teacher Toolbox: Setting Up Remote Routines with Quill](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/teacher-toolbox-setting-up-remote-routines-with-quill)

[Family Toolbox: Start a Quill Classroom at Home](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/family-toolbox-start-a-quill-classroom-at-home)

(Video) [Using Quill Lessons Remotely](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Using_Lessons_Remotely.mp4)

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: Using Quill Lessons as a Remote Resource](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-using-quill-lessons-as-a-remote-resource)

**Use Quill at the end of the school year and during the summer:** The end of the school year is often a time when emotions run high as energy runs out. Quill's ready-to-assign activities are a great option for closing out the school year. Quill's activities also make excellent practice for the summer. We have compiled a few items to help you prepare for this time:

[Tiny Tips for Teachers: 5 Ways to Wrap up the School Year with Quill](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-5-ways-to-wrap-up-the-school-year-with-quill)

[Family Toolbox: Creating a Culture of Writing at Home](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/family-toolbox-creating-a-culture-of-writing-at-home)

[Quill for the Summer](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_for_the_Summer.pdf)

Looking for more information? all of the above articles and videos are available in Quill's [Teacher Center.](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center) If you have additional tips or questions, feel free to reach out to us at hello@quill.org.

Quill's Implementation Library

Quill has 5 different tools and over 600 activities to help students become strong writers. Read on to learn about common implementation strategies and best practice tips for using Quill with your students.

by Maddy M.

title: 4 Tips to Maximize Remote Learning with Quill
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Remote-Learning-image.png)

While nothing replaces the value of face-to-face classroom instruction, [Quill.org](http://quill.org/) provides packs of high-quality, sentence-level writing activities that students can do anytime and anywhere!

Here are 4 tips to maximize remote learning with Quill!

### 1. Take Advantage of the Independent Practice

We recommend that Quill teachers assign activities from our 4 independent practice tools; the Quill Diagnostic, Quill Connect, Quill Proofreader and Quill Grammar. Quill Lessons is designed to be a whole-class, collaborative activity, and is most effective when all participants are together in one room, so we do not recommend using this tool remotely.

### 2. Sequence Your Assignments

If you're looking to keep student skills sharp, assign a writing diagnostic and recommended activities! The diagnostic will identify areas of growth and will generate up to 8 weeks of writing practice tailored specifically to your students' needs! The following articles will guide you through assigning [diagnostics](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049933-how-do-i-assign-a-quill-diagnostic) and [recommendations](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589522-how-do-i-assign-diagnostic-recommendations)!

If you're looking to keep all students on a specific learning track, you can browse through our library of over 600 writing activities and create [customized activity packs](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049954-how-do-i-create-and-assign-a-new-activity-pack) to meet your needs! This article will guide you through customizing packs.

To keep students on track with their independent practice activities, we recommend using the Quill [Due Dates](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1065187-how-can-i-assign-activities-in-a-specific-order) feature.

### 3. Stay on Top of Completed Work

Check out the "Date Completed" statistic on our "[Activity Summary](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work)" page to ensure that students are staying on top of their assignments.

### 4. Help With Skill Transfer

If students are working on another (non-Quill.org) writing project, ask them to highlight evidence of the grammar concepts they’ve learned on Quill.org. Reinforcement supports learning!

title: Tiny Tips for Teachers: 5 Ways to Wrap up the School Year with Quill
body:
As the school year comes to a close, you may have your mind on digital housekeeping: closing out classes, assessing performance, or showing proof of performance. We have compiled several tips on how you can use Quill to end the school year, and what to do with your Quill classes once the year has officially ended.

### **Tip #1: Reassigning a Diagnostic as a Post-Test**

Did you assign a diagnostic at the start of the year or at the beginning of your time on Quill? If so, this same diagnostic would be great to use for a post-test to see if students were able to grasp those concepts throughout their Quill usage. If you assigned more than one for the year, consider reassigning the one where you assigned the [recommended activity packs](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589522-how-do-i-assign-diagnostic-recommendations) for each student.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/posttestdiagnostic.png)
For more guidance on how to set-up a diagnostic as a post test, please review [this article walking you through these steps](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1060357-is-there-a-post-test-diagnostic-that-i-could-assign-to-my-students-at-the-end-of-the-year).

### **Tip #2: The End of Year Requests for Work**

When the end of the year rolls around, you are bombarded with requests from students and families asking for additional practice, an opportunity to boost scores through extra credit, or for a chance to re-do assignments. How you handle this depends on your district or school's policies, your philosophy around school and learning, and your time. Here at Quill, we can assist you with the last piece— time. Below are some ways you can use Quill to meet the needs mentioned above and a few more!

- **Replay to Re-Do Assignments** - Students can re-do any Quill assignments that they have not shown proficiency in by selecting the "Replay" button next to that activity. Have them focus their efforts on activities in the [yellow or red proficiency bands](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049935-how-does-quill-grade-activities). If you want more tips on helping students replay successfully, check out the article ["Tiny Tips for Teachers: Encouraging Replay for Recall."](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/tiny-tips-for-teachers-encourage-replay-for-improved-recall)
- **Finish To-Do Activities** - Students may have unfinished assignments to tend to before the end of the year. On your teacher dashboard, you can easily determine who has not completed work by checking the [Activity Summary student report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work).  You may dedicate some final days of the school year to completing any unfinished activities. When directing students to complete incomplete or not-started activities, have them navigate to the "To Do Activities" listed on their [student dashboard.](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/3812794-what-does-the-student-dashboard-look-like)

Either of the strategies above, a student can do with a peer who is also working on their own unique set of work, giving students the added benefit of talking out answers with someone else for boosted retention!

### **Tip #3: Creating a Quill "Report Card" for Students & Families**

The [Activity Scores report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1650560-how-do-i-read-the-activity-scores-report) allows you to print out individual .pdf reports for each of your students. This report averages the percentage of your student's completed Quill activities and creates one overall Quill score, as well as presenting an average score for each activity pack. This might be useful for your grading, for student reporting, and can be presented to parents as it is a clean way of viewing Quill performance.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/shakespeareactivityscores.png)
This report is available to all [Quill Premium](https://www.quill.org/premium) users, and can be found by selecting the [Student Reports](https://www.quill.org/teachers/progress_reports/activities_scores_by_classroom) tab.

### **Tip #4: Archiving Classes**

This step is near last for an important reason. Archiving classes remove students' ability to enter that class and complete assignments, as well as your capacity to review the data reports for this class.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/archivingquillclass.png)
To archive a class, follow the steps listed in [this article about managing classes](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049946-how-do-i-manage-my-classes-and-my-students). We do not permanently delete classes at Quill, so you could always choose to unarchive a class at a later date, should you need to.

### **Tip #5: Create a Summer Quill Classroom**

Once the course for the previous year is archived, you may want to create a summer Quill classroom for students and families interested in extra practice over the break! This is optional, and you can take a hands-off approach if you choose!

**Setting Up the Summer Class**
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/createsummerclass.png)

**Students Manually Join Using Email of Choice**

If you are assigning this as optional practice for those who want it, do not create accounts for students over the summer. You can select "Students create their own accounts." Selecting that option will take you to a link you can share with students and families interested in signing up for summer practice!
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/addstudentssummerclass.png)
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/classcodesummerstudents.png)

**What Activities Should You Include?**

For summer activities, you can load independent practice activities from the grade students are exiting. To do this, filter by CCSS grade level.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/ccsssummergrades.png)

**Note:** It may be helpful when setting up this option to share with families appropriate channels for summer support such as emailing [support@quill.org](mailto:support@quill.org) or visiting the [support page](http://support.quill.org/). Families and students won't need to rely on you this summer to complete the practice, allowing you to unplug! *For an even more hands-off approach, you can also suggest to families that they create their own summer classroom, giving them even more control of the process.*

title: Best Practices: How to Support Students During Independent Practice
body:
Quill's content, even the supplemental practice, is designed to help teachers maximize their instruction. By engaging with students while they practice their grammar, teachers can provide the impactful intervention that students need to become the best writers they can be.

While Quill's independent practice activities allow students to work on their specific areas of need, teachers can still engage with the class and provide meaningful instruction and support. Here are some ways teachers support students working independently on Quill Activities:

**Tip #1: Issue important Quill reminders**

Remind students of the three constants of Quill. We recommend having these three rules written or projected on the board while students work on their Quill activities.

1. Read the directions, prompts, and models carefully.
2. Check for correct spelling, punctuation, capitalization, and spacing.
3. Consider your choices—Quill accepts any grammatically correct answer that uses the activity's grammar targets.

**Tip #2: Keep an eye out for orange**

On Quill, we prompt students to revise their work with orange feedback. While students are working on their independent practice activities, take a walk around the room and keep an eye out for students receiving a lot of orange feedback. Use the orange feedback as an opportunity to identify students that may need additional support, and then intervene with those students either as they work through the activity, one-on-one following the activity, or in a small group following the activity.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-05-05_at_2.20.57_PM__1_.png)

**Tip #3: Ask guiding questions**

While Quill works hard to create widely accessible prompts, we understand that there may be concepts in our questions that students are not yet familiar with. Asking students some guiding questions to make sure they understand some of the details of the actual content of the sentence that they might be missing.

For example, here is a prompt form one of our advanced combining activities:

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-06-17_at_10.52.13_AM.png)

Guiding questions here could include:

*To ensure that students understand the political climate of South Africa that this question addresses:* "Why did South Africa need to be brought together?"

*To ensure that students understand what an activist is*: "What do you think it means to be a non-violent activist?"

*To ensure that students understand what the Nobel Peace Price is:* "Why would a non-violent activist win the Nobel Peace Prize?"

**Tip #4:** **Engage in guided practice**

Using a Quill independent practice activity as a whole-class activity before students go off on their own is a great way of modeling the desired concepts. This way, students can see some common mistakes that might occur, in addition to understanding how Quill works when they submit a wrong or right answer.

**Tip #5: Encourage small group work**

For concepts that are particularly difficult for students, it might be beneficial to have students in small groups or partners to discuss through the activity and the feedback they receive.

title: Best Practices: How to use Quill when you don't have time for the diagnostic
body:
Whether you're implementing Quill partway through the year, or your schedule just does not allow for 8-10 weeks of recommended content, Quill still offers quick-to-assign, easy-to-modify practice beyond just the [Diagnostic](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049933-how-do-i-assign-a-quill-diagnostic) and [Diagnostic Recommendations](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589522-how-do-i-assign-diagnostic-recommendations). All of our activities, regardless of how teachers choose to assign them, serve immediate feedback to help students learn to revise their work and become strong, detail-oriented writers. Here are a few tips to provide quick, easy, and targeted instruction to your students without assigning a Diagnostic.

### **Assigning Options**

**Option 1: Use the [Featured Activity Packs](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049944-how-do-i-assign-a-featured-activity-pack)**

If you're looking for 2-3 weeks of concept-focused independent practice, this route is for you. Quill has over [75 pre-made activity packs](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049944-how-do-i-assign-a-featured-activity-pack), each with 10-20 activities, that focus on specific grammar concepts and skill levels. We break packs down by "independent practice" and "whole-class and independent practice," and then sort all packs by skill level (starter, intermediate, and advanced), so that teachers can easily sort through and locate the content they need.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-06-05_at_3.24.56_PM.png)

**Option 2: [Build a customized pack](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049954-how-do-i-create-and-assign-a-new-activity-pack) to fit your students' needs**

Quill has over 600 activities to choose from. Teachers can [filter through our library](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Video_Tutorials_-_Navigating_Quill_Search_v3.mp4) of activities by tool type, common core standard, or concept and build packs of any length.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-06-05_at_3.25.04_PM.png)

### **Implementation Tips**

**Tip #1: Use Quill activities for immediate intervention**

If you notice that your students are struggling with certain grammar concepts in their writing, use Quill activities to provide instruction and practice as needed. Both of the assignment options above can help you identify and assign a Quill activity (or activities) that aligns to the demonstrated needs of your students.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/fullsizeoutput_19a2__1_.jpeg)

**Tip #2: Use Quill in Station Rotations**

Station rotations are a great way to keep your class engaged and provide them with a breadth of practice. Quill independent practice activities take 10-15 minutes to complete, making them the perfect stop in a station rotation.

**Tip #3: Use Quill as paired practice**

If you have limited device access or you want to keep all of your students on the same page, have students work through Quill activities in pairs. Students can either work through the questions on separate devices and compare feedback, or they can work on the same activity on the same device and write out the sentences together. This way, students can discuss the feedback they receive, bounce ideas off of each other, and help each other improve their writing skills.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/fullsizeoutput_1a0a__1_.jpeg)

**Tip 4: Use a Quill Lesson to change things up**

[Quill Lessons](https://www.quill.org/tools/lessons) are a whole-class, interactive, customizable platform for introducing grammar concepts. If you're looking for an engaging method of discussing grammar, lead a Quill Lesson once every 2-3 weeks to keep students thinking about writing. [Lessons are customizable](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1310486-how-do-i-customize-a-quill-lesson), so you can easily center the presentation around the unit you're working on in class.

title: Quill.org: A Brief History
body:
Quill.org was hatched by Peter Gault and a group of Brooklyn-based innovators inspired by the internet's capacity to give everyone a voice. In 2014, Gault, a former member of his school's debate team, sought to develop a tool that helped students hone critical thinking skills and engage in active, intelligent debate and discourse. As the team set out on this mission, they quickly realized that the first step on their journey would be to help young people level up their basic writing skills so that they could effectively communicate their thoughts and ideas.

As Gault and the team explored the best ways to support students with online learning, they came across an article that helped define Quill's mission of supporting low-income schools: *[The Writing Revolution](https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2012/10/the-writing-revolution/309090/)* by Peg Tyre. Tyre's work calls for schools to provide more comprehensive writing instruction to give students the strong foundation they need to hone literacy skills.

Taking the lessons they learned from their early research, the Quill team launched the [Quill Proofreader](https://www.quill.org/tools/proofreader) tool in 2014 to help teachers spot students who needed support. Shortly after, they added independent activities for practice—the foundations of our [Quill Grammar](https://www.quill.org/tools/grammar) tool. The Quill team also developed the first iteration of their Quill Student Reports during this time to help teachers help their students improve upon challenging grammar concepts. Quill, however, has always had more far-reaching ambitions than simply teaching grammar. To move Quill closer to its goal of helping all students become strong writers and critical thinkers, Quill took on new engineering challenges to create increasingly sophisticated tools.

The team took Quill's tools to the next level in 2016 with the launch of [Quill Connect](https://www.quill.org/tools/connect) and the first [diagnostic assessment and recommendations series](https://www.quill.org/tools/diagnostic). The innovation of an online sentence combining tool that served instant feedback to students quickly garnered Quill notoriety amongst major players in both the education and technology spaces, earning Quill large grants, headlines in *Forbes,* and a top 10 spot on [*Fast Company's* World's Most Innovative Companies list in 2018.](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/fast-company-selects-quillorg-as-one-of-the-worlds-most-innovative-companies-for-2018/) As the Quill team continued to work towards its goals, they launched even more content accessible to a wider range of students, including the ELL Diagnostic and the [Quill Lessons](https://www.quill.org/tools/lessons) tool in 2017. At that point, the word had gotten out; Quill was a major player in the edtech space.

In the past few years, the organization has received major grants and great support from Google AI for Social Good, the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative, the Lone Pine Foundation, and many more. The generosity of these organizations has enabled us to continue forward on our path to helping every student across the country become a strong writer. In 2019, we were able to launch several more levels of Diagnostic and begin work on our most innovative writing tool yet, set to launch in the fall of 2020.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Volleyball_History_Timeline_Infographic__1_.jpg)

title: What 10 Million Questions Answered Looks Like on Quill
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/10_Million_Sentences.png)

On March 28, 2016, the Quill office was brimming with excitement. After filling our mugs with coffee, the team huddled around our results monitor, anticipating our biggest milestone to date: 10 million questions answered by Quill students.

Since launching last fall, more than 210,000 students and 14,000 teachers have signed up for Quill. Over the last year and a half, we have personally worked with hundreds of dedicated and inspiring educators. Their feedback has enabled us to continuously improve Quill, benefiting all students. Even more gratifying is the time we are able to spend in classrooms interacting directly with students and personally listening to teachers.

Quill’s mission is to help every student become a better writer. Your help in accomplishing this major milestone cannot be overstated; we rely on educators and learners within our Quill community every day, and could not be more grateful for your support. We’re on our way to building a platform that provides every student with high-quality, personalized instruction in writing.

title: Quill Fall Internship Reflection
body:
I’ve always been very hesitant about education technology, so when I applied to work at Quill.org, I wasn’t exactly sure what I was getting myself into. It was important to me that Quill.org was a nonprofit, and I loved the idea of helping teach students necessary grammar skills, primarily with a focus on disadvantaged schools and communities. However, I worried about the effectiveness of online content and the role that it might play in the classroom.

Despite my initial concerns, I wasn’t disappointed at all. I quickly understood the efforts Quill.org makes to educate in a productive manner, and I saw how much teachers loved the site, using it both in and out of the classroom. I learned about how infrequently grammar is taught in the classroom, and how difficult it can be to find strong resources to teach it to students of all ages. I became invested in their mission and am proud of what I was able to accomplish during my time here to learn and grow with Quill.org.

My main project during my time at Quill.org was to find a way to let teachers submit usable activities to our site. We receive so many requests from teachers asking to make their own activities, and I wanted to find a way to help them do so in an efficient manner. I first researched open educational resources and wrote an article on what sources are usable when creating an activity. I then created a submission document for both proofreader and grammar activities, including all relevant information needed for submission, from aligned Common Core State Standard to activity subject. I learned so much about Common Core State Standards and how to shape activities around them to ensure mastery by students.

I then wrote a step-by-step article for assignment submission so that teachers will be entirely clear on the expectations of their submitted content. One concept that I emphasized was the need for diversity in content. Since we strive to make our content academic, I wanted to ensure that we were not only giving students informative content, but also a wider variety of content than is traditionally included in curricula. I was in contact with the DEAP school, a Navajo school New Mexico, to figure out what content they would like to see, particularly within the realm of the Navajo Nation and other Native American communities. In my step-by-step, I encouraged teachers submitting content to focus on information that isn’t always found in textbooks, such as information on Native American culture, or features on LGBT figures. I also wrote some activities myself using the format I had created, studying topics as I shaped them into constructive activities. I created a form to be sent out when a teacher’s activity is approved, and drafted email responses to teacher submissions to make the submission process as easy as possible for both my teammates and the people who submit.

In addition to my main project, I helped out with many other smaller jobs. I wrote over ten articles on our FAQ site, as well as worked with our help site to assist both teachers and students with technical and content issues. I wrote bug reports when teachers ran into issues and collaborated with our team to think of new ideas for Quill.org’s site.

I also helped out with writing needed activities, reviewing those created by others, and writing emails for all users. I contacted individual teachers for feedback and suggestions. Finally, I attended a few development sessions at schools in the New York City area to help our Partnerships Director inform teachers on how to best use our site. It was amazing to see how eager teachers were to integrate Quill.org’s activities into their classrooms, and how receptive they were to the site’s many functions.

One of my favorite parts of Quill.org was the size of the team. Since there are only eight people on our team, it was easy to communicate and interact with everyone– I knew where problems went when I reported them, and it was easy to bring up ideas or issues. Everyone was so excited and passionate about Quill.org and worked tirelessly to make it flow.

All in all, interning at Quill.org was a memorable and educational experience. I learned so much about Common Core State Standards and their implementation, relevant content development, and the importance of grammar. I improved my skills in customer service when working the help site, and even learned a bit of coding when I submitted my activities to the website. As I continue to develop my career in education, I know that I will look back on my time here as an important step toward my goals and growth.

title: Quill at iLearnNYC Innovation Institute
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_iLearn_JJ_post.png)

Quill is built from teacher ideas and feedback. On November 8th, we visited Brooklyn’s John Dewey High School to participate in the iLearnNYC Innovation Institute, a free day of learning that prepares NYC teachers to use a range of cutting-edge technologies and promote school transformation.

We gave teachers from all over the city their first go at Quill, and they gave us some valuable insight. Here’s what we learned.

*1. Personalization is the vehicle for engagement*

One teacher at our session appreciated that, with Quill, “you can have students work specifically on the concepts they misused.” This comment highlights the fact that the best education technology uses provides individualized feedback and interactivity to hold a student’s attention from the moment they’re asked a question to the moment they’ve produced a satisfactory answer — and every moment in between. This fact is often overlooked. Many digital tools are static and set one inalterable pace for the entire class. Some students are never challenged; others never have the opportunity to catch up.

*2. Learning requires effort after errors*

One teacher noted that “when you make a mistake [in Quill], you have to fix it yourself.” Rather than simply revealing your error, the program “walks you through each change, step by step.” Quill gives students the authority to make decisions when writing, even if that means they make mistakes. When students make errors using Quill, they use hints and feedback to make their own changes, rather than getting the correct answer and cut the learning experience short. Quill gives them multiple chances to change their responses. Teachers can aid in this process by asking questions: “What do you think you might have missed?” “What parts of the sentence confused you?” “Can you read your answer aloud to see where there might be an error?” Instruct students to take the time they need on each sentence to read and write with precision. When students work deliberately toward typing a correct sentence without help, they retain their new skills more effectively.

*3. Digital tools can impact even classrooms with limited technology access*

Many teachers in the room expressed a lack of 1-to-1 access to computers in their classrooms. It’s crucial that Edtech companies address this, and build it into their products. Quill’s answer to this is threefold:

* Students can complete group exercises and take part in group lessons from their smartphones/tablets. At many schools, there will be far more smartphones than computers available in a classroom.
* Quill’s supplementary nature allows teachers to rotate students through Quill’s activities at different times, or in small groups. Quill is an important piece of your ELA or ELL instruction, to be worked in with the rest of the curriculum.
* Quill provides opportunities for dialogue. Teachers can project any Quill activity to the whole class, and engage students in discussion surrounding their choices.

We’d like to thank everyone who attended our iLearn session. Because we’re open-source, the teacher input we received at this event (and every day) strengthens Quill for all users. We’ll be back for the next Innovation Institute in January!
subtitle: At the iLearn Innovation Institute, we gave teachers from all over New York City their first go at Quill, and they gave us some valuable insight. Here’s what we learned.
