title: How Do The Most Popular EdTech Polling Tools Compare?
body:
Formative assessment tools such as “exit slips” have become the norm in the classroom as a way to check in with students to inform the pacing of future lessons. Fortunately, many online tools exist to ease the process gathering formative assessments during a lesson to make it easier to check in with students. Each tool on the market has features that make them unique and impact the experience and pacing of the lesson in different ways. The most common tools at the moment are **[Kahoot](https://getkahoot.com/?utm_name=controller_app&utm_source=web_app&utm_medium=link), [Socrative](https://www.socrative.com/), [Quizlet Live](https://quizlet.com/),** and **[Nearpod](https://nearpod.com/).** Each of these tools have been evaluated based on how they can be used specifically for the purpose of formative assessment in the classroom during lessons. For teachers, lesson planning is a delicate balance between ensuring that lessons are not too challenging for students, while still encouraging growth and learning, and each tool has a different approach to finding the right balance.

# Kahoot

***Pros:*** *Students can access the quizzes quickly and easily.*

***Cons:*** *Students can only view the questions on one screen in front of the classroom. This might make it difficult for some students to follow along while the lesson is taking place.*

**What makes Kahoot unique?**

Teachers can create their own quiz or select from the many free options of quizzes that other teachers have created. In addition to multiple choice, Kahoot offers “Jumble Quizzes” which allows students to order answers into a correct sequence. This is great for history or science lessons if you want to test memory for answers that require a correct order or sequence. Kahoot is the only tool of the four that offers points or rankings to students for correctly answering questions. Teachers can easily customize the experience by selecting whether or not they want the rankings to be visible to students.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Kahoot.png)
*Teachers can easily customize the experience by selecting whether or not they want the rankings to be visible to students.*


It is also the only tool that offers a “2 step join” which offers an extra step before joining for added security. When 2-step join is enabled, players need to enter the tile pattern on their devices in addition to a PIN to be able to join the game. This prevents users who are not physically in the classroom from joining in.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Kahoot_Orange.png)
*When 2-step join is enabled, players need to enter the tile pattern on their devices in addition to a PIN.*


While using Kahoot, it is important to consider the fact that transitions between questions are very quick. This leaves very little time in between questions for teachers to discuss answers with students. Teachers also need to consider how much technology they have available in the classroom since questions for students are only displayed in the teacher’s view. This means that a projector or a smart screen is needed to display the questions while each student needs a device for full classroom participation.

**Usability as a formative assessment tool:**

Teachers can download the results of their students’ quizzes as reports at the end of the lessons to their Google Drive or as an Excel spreadsheet. However, there is no way for teachers to see individual students’ answers during the duration of the lesson. While Kahoot is an excellent tool for polling students, it may be difficult to integrate into lessons as a formative assessment tool.

# Socrative
***Pros:***  *While creating the quizzes, teachers can add their own feedback to appear in addition to the correct answer. Teachers can also include open ended questions in their quizzes.*

***Cons:*** *During the lesson, teachers can’t view which students have completed the questions or what they have written during the lesson.*

*What makes Socrative unique?*

When teachers sign up, they are assigned a classroom and a PIN code that students can use to login to their classroom. Once the teacher has signed into their account, they can choose which quiz to launch in the classroom for their students to see. While creating quizzes, teachers can also include their own customized feedback which appears on their students’ screens in addition to the right answer. Teachers also have the option of adding open ended questions which students can respond to by typing out their answers.

While Socrative does not have a point system like Kahoot, it does offer a quiz option that is in the form of a game to increase student engagement. Quizzes that teachers create can be launched as a team game called Space Race where students compete by answering a series of multiple choice questions. Each correct answer moves the rocket one step further. Teachers can customize the experience by selecting up to 20 teams. Students can be auto assigned to a team or select a team for themselves once they login. Regardless of the number of students in a team, all it takes is one right answer for the rocket to move. This makes it a good option if there are limited devices in the classroom since students can share a device to answer questions together in small groups.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Socrative_Space_Race.png)
*Quizzes that teachers create can be launched as a team game called Space Race.*

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Socrative_Space_Race_2.png)

**Usability as a formative assessment tool:**

Like Kahoot, reports can be can be downloaded on Google Drive, as a .pdf and as an Excel document. After the quiz, teachers have the option to view the results of the whole class, individual students and specific questions. During the quiz teachers can see how many students have answered the question, however they can’t view their answers until the end of the quiz. Students can sign onto the quiz both with and without their logins which means that if teachers want to collect their reports, students have to be logged in otherwise they will lose their data if they get disconnected.

# Quizlet Live

***Pros***: *Questions are designed in a way that encourages discussion and teamwork.*

***Cons:*** *Teachers can’t write open ended questions into the quiz.*

**What makes Quizlet unique?**

Quizlet Live poses the questions differently to most multiple choice questions. Students participate in teams where all participants have a different set of potential answers to the question. To answer the question correctly, students are required to communicate and collaborate with each other to figure out which one of them has the correct answer. Since students are not required to look at a projector in the front of the classroom, teachers have more flexibility with the classroom set up and spacing. For instance you can have students work in small groups both inside and outside the classroom.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Sansa.png)

**Usability as a formative assessment tool:**

Since there is only one right answer amongst all the students, the quiz facilitates teamwork and and promotes discussion about the terms. Teachers can listen to these discussions to understand the thought process of their students.

While Quizlet Live is a great tool for definitions and vocabulary building, there are some limitations that teachers have while creating the quizzes. Teachers must have a minimum of 12 questions before they can initiate the quiz and only have the option of creating multiple choice or true/false questions.

# Nearpod

***Pros:***  *Teachers can view student activity during the lesson and select what students can and can’t see. Teachers can choose from lessons and edit slides to customize them for their class.*

***Cons:*** *Teachers can’t track student assessments over time.*

**What makes Nearpod unique?**

Nearpod is the only tool that allows for students to interact with the questions by drawing directly on the page.Teachers can then view which students have completed the activity and which students are still working. Teachers can also view exactly what each student has written and can then showcase student work by selecting their screen to share with the rest of the class.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Nearpod.png)

**Usability as a formative assessment tool:**

After the questions are answered, teachers can instantly view the results of a quiz. They are given the name of each student and how they answered. This information can also be viewed in the form of a graph which can also be shared with students. The fact that teachers can instantly view how students have answered questions makes it an excellent formative assessment tool since teachers can change the pacing of the lesson based on the needs of the students.

**How can the experience be improved?**

Even if students are signed into student accounts, all four tools require students to login with a PIN and enter their name every time they use it. This means that the reports are saved by quiz name rather than student. As a result, teachers can’t easily track student assessment over time or have one place to store their results. The experience could be improved if teachers could search for students by name and easily access all the reports pertaining to each of the students in their classroom.
subtitle: Analyzing the Pros and Cons of Kahoot, Socrative, Quizlet Live, and Nearpod

title: Quill is Open Sourcing NLP Tools To Aid Student Writing
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Open_Sourcing.png)
An example of detecting parts of speech. Quill uses parts of speech detection in its sentence fragment tool.

*Imagine a student writing, “My favorite writer is J.K. Rowling, she is very descriptive.”*

In the example above, a student has written a sentence fragment. In the United States, [**75% of students**](https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2012/10/the-writing-revolution/309090/) struggle with writing, and these students often struggle with fragments and run-on sentences. Here’s how one teacher describes his students’ writing,

*“[Students] produced massive run-on sentences connected by a long series of and’s, while still others scattered sentence fragments throughout their compositions.”*

Computer programs often cannot detect or remediate these errors. When you look at the state of the art in sentence fragment detection today, you see abysmal results. In our test of 100 sentence fragments, **Programs like Microsoft Word and Google Docs were able to correctly detect, at best, 30% of the fragments.** Students rely on these tools to improve their writing, and they need better solutions.

Quill.org’s free online tools help students become strong writers, and to date, the organization has helped over 300,000 students improve their skills. For a couple of years, however, Quill did not detect sentence fragments, and one of the most common pieces of feedback we heard from teachers is that their students need sentence fragment remediation.

Quill is now building a machine learning powered fragment detection algorithm to detect and remediate fragment errors, and[ **today, we have open sourced our fragment detection algorithm**](https://github.com/empirical-org/Quill-NLP-Tools-and-Datasets). ***In our tests, our algorithm can accurately detect fragments 84% of the time***, and we aim to launch the algorithm by September 1st, 2017 .

The Quill team does not have a machine learning expert on staff. Instead, our developer team was able to solve this problem by using online courses and open source tools. Specifically, we used Udacity’s [**machine learning course**](https://www.udacity.com/course/machine-learning-engineer-nanodegree--nd009), and we highly recommend to other software engineers who are interested in machine learning. For Quill, we were able to successfully implement a machine learning solution because we had a discrete problem with two potential outcomes — either a text string is a sentence or a fragment. For larger problems you may need an expert, but if you have the right problem, you can solve it yourself.

Here’s how we were able to solve our detection problem. To start, Quill turned to the machine learning research. Researchers at the [**City University of Hong Kong**](http://www.aclweb.org/anthology/P15-2099) used a combination of Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning to detect sentence fragments. Machine learning requires a large data set, and these researchers were using 100,000 sentences pulled from Reuters newspaper articles. The data set and code were closed sourced, however, and required an expensive license to access the data. Quill set out to build a free, open source fragment detection tool that any organization could use to help people understand and remediate fragment errors, and we needed an open source data set.

Here’s how our implementation works:

1. **Compile Wikipedia dataset:** Wikipedia’s [**featured articles**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Featured_articles) have been reviewed by multiple editors and locked to ensure accuracy. We pulled 100,000 highly-edited sentences from these articles.

2. **Build training data:** To detect whether a sentence is a fragment or a complete sentence, you need a large data set that contains both types of sentences. We took the 100,000 sentences, and turned half of them into fragments by using Spacy.io, a natural language processing tool. Spacy.io enabled us to turn each sentence into a parts of speech string (“I run” becomes “I: Subject, Run: Verb”). We then removed certain parts of speech from the sentences, such as the subject, verb, or dependent clause. We now had 50,000 fragments.

3. **Make a numerical representation of the data:** We now need to label the data. The classifier needs two sets of data, inputs and labels. The labels are a binary value of either 1 or 0, where 1 indicates the inputs represent a sentence, and 0 represents a fragment. For inputs we convert the fragments and sentences in lists of their parts of speech and create trigrams of the parts of speech. A trigram is a group of three parts of speech. For example, “subject verb noun” is one trigram. For efficacy, we only used the 1,200 most common trigrams. For each sentence and fragment we create a 1,200 value array that represents the trigrams it contains.

4. **Feed the data into the classifier:** We reserve 10% of the data for testing, and use the other 90% of the data rest for building the model. We then fed the data into Tensorflow. We have 1,200 input nodes followed by a 200 node hidden layer and a second hidden layer of 25 nodes. We then output to 2 nodes, one for each each outcome, sentence or fragment.

5. **Analyze the fragments:** Our team manually created a set of 100 fragments and sentences, and we ran these sentences through the algorithm. While we know whether the sentence was a complete sentence or a fragment, the algorithm does not, and it makes a judgement of whether it is a complete sentence or a fragment. By comparing the algorithm’s judgements to our data set, we found that the algorithm accurately detected fragments 84% of the time, and we aim to increase the accuracy by working with the open source community. One area we can improve for example, is detecting short sentences. We found that short sentences were hard to detect as they were under-represented in the data set.

As a nonprofit, open source organization building free writing tools, we invite everyone to join us. You can join us on our [**slack channel**](https://community.quill.org/join-slack/) or follow our Medium for updates. We will continue to share what we are learning and welcome your thoughts.

**Ready to dive into the code?** You can take a further look at the code [**here.**](https://github.com/empirical-org/Quill-NLP-Tools-and-Datasets) The Readme file is a complete walkthrough of the code need to prepare and model the data. You can run and modify the code by cloning the repo and running [**Jupyter Notebooks**](http://jupyter.org/) from the directory. You’ll need to have Python 3.5 installed. Feel free to open a pull request or issue for any feedback you have.

title: Best Practices: How to use Quill to teach ELL students
body:
## Best Practices: Supporting ELL Students on Quill

English language acquisition requires patience, practice, and deliberate instruction. Quill's features provide ELL students with the differentiated practice they need to grow in their English acquisition at their own pace, all while providing instructors with unique insights into the student writing process.

Like our other diagnostic assessments, the ELL Diagnostics evaluate student skill level and then provide differentiated instruction for every single student based on their demonstrated areas of need. These assessments ensure that no concept is glossed over.

Quill's ELL Diagnostics and recommendations introduce foundational grammar skills before having students practice these concepts in context. We currently have two assessments; the Starter ELL Diagnostic and the ELL Diagnostic.

 **The ELL Starter Diagnostic**

- Designed for students who are new to the English language
- Helps students build a strong grammar foundation

**The ELL Diagnostic**

- Designed for English Language Learning students that already have a foundation in English
- Helps students practice basic foundational skills with full-sentence practice

## Tips for using the ELL Diagnostics


### Tip #1: Use Quill's Built-In Scaffolds

*Prompt and Direction Translations*

Quill is committed to providing differentiated learning experiences for students. To support ELL students, we've built in a  feature that translates the directions and prompts for the ELL Diagnostics into 16 different languages.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-04-22_at_3.15.47_PM.png)

*Vocabulary PDFs*

For students brand new to the English language, Quill offers a series of [vocabulary PDFs](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/topic/teacher-materials) to support students working through the Starter Diagnostic Recommendations. These vocabulary PDFs provide students with the content context that they need  to successfully complete the grammatical practice.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-04-22_at_4.27.07_PM.png)

### Tip #2: Use the Recommended Quill Lessons and Customization Features

When classes complete a Diagnostic assessment, Quill recommends whole-class Lessons that target areas of need based on class-wide performance.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_org___Interactive_Writing_and_Grammar__17_.png)

If students need additional support, you can customize your Lesson to provide additional content context, translations, and more explicit breakdowns of grammar concepts.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-04-22_at_4.41.07_PM.png)

## External Scaffolds for ELL Students Using Quill

### Tip #3: Use Browser Extensions

For students that need additional English language acquisition support, we recommend downloading [browser extensions that are compatible with Quill and can aid students in a variety of ways.](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1058670-free-extensions-for-students-with-modifications-iep-ell)

### Tip #4: Work in opportunities for oral practice

 Once students have completed their Quill work, oral practice is a great way to initiate skill transfer! Try this model with your class:

*Do 1x every 2 weeks:*

1. Students send their teacher their favorite sentence they wrote on Quill that day
2. Working together as a class (or one-on-one over a voice recording, if you're teaching remotely), have students practice combining their classmate's favorite sentences out loud with new conjunctions.

EX:

Student's favorite sentence: The bear hibernated because it was winter.

Teacher-provided conjunction: *since*

New student sentence (orally): The bear hibernated since it was winter.

title: Recursos de Quill.org para docentes y padres afectados por el cierre de escuelas durante la emergencia sanitaria
body:
**¿Es un docente o un progenitor que quiere ayudar a sus estudiantes o a sus hijos a mejorar sus habilidades de escritura mediante herramientas de aprendizaje en línea?** ¡Quill.org está aquí para ayudarle! Ofrecemos más de 600 actividades gratuitas que ayudan a los estudiantes para que se les de bien escribir. A medida que los estudiantes trabajan en las actividades de Quill, realizamos comentarios de manera inmediata con el fin de que los estudiantes puedan revisar su trabajo de manera eficaz y desarrollar rápidamente sus habilidades de escritura. Lo primero que hacemos es llevar a cabo evaluaciones de diagnóstico cuya finalidad es que puedan ver qué habilidades deben practicar sus hijos y después, con un solo clic, puede asignarle esas actividades de práctica. ¡Es muy fácil! **Este es un mensaje para los padres, tutores y familias: Quill es 100 % gratuito para todo el mundo, no solo para los docentes.** Lo único que tiene que hacer es registrarse como educador, a continuación añada a su hijo/a o hijos como estudiantes en su clase. La misión de Quill, sin animo de lucro, es proporcionar herramientas y materiales de aprendizaje gratuitos para todos los estudiantes, docentes y familias. Además de nuestras herramientas gratuitas, queríamos informarles sobre otras formas en que los apoyaremos durante esta crisis.
---
## **1. Quill Prémium gratis para todos los educadores (¡docentes y padres!)** A partir del 18 de marzo de 2020, todos los educadores (docentes, padres y tutores) tendrán acceso gratuito a Quill Prémium para docentes. Con el fin de obtener acceso, solo tiene que hacer clic en el siguiente enlace y activaremos inmediatamente el Prémium para docentes y la suscripción gratuita estará activa hasta julio de 2020. Active Quill Prémium gratis para docentes Quill Prémium para docentes le proporciona informes adicionales para comprender mejor el progreso de sus alumnos, así como la posibilidad de descargar y exportar los informes en formato PDF o CSV con la finalidad de que pueda compartir estos datos con otros educadores, administradores y padres.
[Más información sobre Quill Prémium para docentes.](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1068118-what-do-i-get-with-a-premium-subscription) También ofrecemos a los administradores del distrito Quill Prémium. Todo su distrito podrá utilizar Quill Prémium y acceder a informes adicionales. Si quiere solicitar Quill Prémium para todo el distrito, complete este formulario y un miembro de nuestro equipo le ayudará.
[Formulario de solicitud de Quill Premium gratis para los distritos](https://forms.gle/ePA3C866hfKkN6BRA)

---
## **2. Chat de preguntas y respuestas sin cita previa - ¡Pregúntenos lo que quiera!** A partir del 19 de marzo de 2020, ¡Quill proporcionará horas para realizar consultas sin cita previa dos veces al día! Por favor, [pásese por el chat](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/live-question-answer-chat) para hacer cualquier pregunta que pueda tener y le ayudaremos en todo lo que podamos. ¡Nuestro equipo de instructores expertos en escritura puede ayudarle a empezar con Quill, recomendarle estrategias de escritura que pueden asistir a sus hijos o puede entrar en el chat y charlar sobre lo que quiera! **Únase a nosotros de lunes a viernes a cualquiera de estas horas:** 1. 9:00 A.M - 10:00 A.M. EDT 2. 12:00 P.M. - 1:00 P.M. EDT presentes en la sala. Queremos asegurarnos de que respondemos completamente a sus necesidades y le agradecemos que nos haga cualquier pregunta que pueda tener. ¡Entre en la sección de preguntas y respuestas y charle con nuestro equipo!
---
## **3. Las mejores prácticas para utilizar Quill en un entorno de aprendizaje remoto** Para ayudarle a empezar a utilizar Quill de una manera eficaz, hemos creado un conjunto de recursos. Estas guías y vídeos pueden ayudarle a empezar a utilizar Quill y después seguir el progreso de sus estudiantes e hijos a medida que desarrollan sus habilidades de escritura. **Consejos de enseñanza para el aprendizaje a distancia**
[Las practicas recomendadas para docentes a la hora de utilizar Quill en un entorno de aprendizaje remoto](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/4-tips-to-maximize-remote-learning-with-quill)
[Consejos de prácticas recomendas para los padres que utilizan Quill en casa](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/using-quill-as-a-homeschool-educator)
**Tutoriales rápidos: cuatro pasos fáciles para empezar a utilizar Quill**
*¡Se tarda menos de 5 minutos en registrarse, prepararlo todo y empezar a aprender!*
**Paso uno:** [Sign Up](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/3956201-como-me-registro-como-docente-how-do-i-sign-up-as-a-teacher)
**Paso dos:** [crear una clase](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/3956198-como-creo-clases-how-do-i-create-classes)
**Paso tres:** [añadir estudiantes](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/3956197-como-invito-anado-estudiantes-a-mis-clases-how-do-i-invite-add-students-to-my-classes)
**Paso cuatro:** empiece por [asignar el diagnóstico](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/3956194-como-asigno-un-diagnostico-de-quill-how-do-i-assign-a-quill-diagnostic) y después [asigne las actividades de aprendizaje recomendadas](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/3956187-como-asigno-las-recomendaciones-de-diagnostico-how-do-i-assign-diagnostic-recommendations) once students complete the diagnostic.

**Aproveche los informes de datos de Quill**
*Quill proporciona información valiosa sobre el rendimiento de los estudiantes en la escritura, sin importar dónde estén usted o sus estudiantes. Vea nuestros 6 informes de gran repercusión:* **Siempre disponible:**
[Resumen de la actividad](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work)
[Análisis de la actividad](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589337-how-do-i-read-the-activity-analysis)
[Informe de diagnóstico](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589441-how-do-i-read-the-diagnostics-report)

title: Using Quill as a Homeschool Educator
body:
Quill can be a valuable resource for homeschool teachers seeking unique ways to help students sharpen their grammar, vocabulary and writing skills. Even at home, you can use Quill’s resources in many of the same ways as a teacher in a traditional classroom would.

# Sign up and create your class
Go to our website and click ‘Sign Up’ to create a teacher account.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices1.png)

Next, click on the ‘Classes’ tab and create a class after naming it and choosing a grade level.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices2.png)

There are a few ways students can join your class. Your student or child can create their accounts themselves and then enter the class code, or you can create accounts for them. If you choose the latter, students’ passwords will be their last name by default. A third route is syncing your class with Google Classroom, so students can log into Quill using their Google accounts.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices3.png)

# Find and assign activities
Once your classroom is set up and your student or child has joined, you can proceed to assigning activities. Go to the ‘Assign Activities’ tab on your teacher dashboard and select ‘Explore All Activities.’

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices4.png)

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices5.png)

From here, you can access our entire catalog of over 500 K-12 lessons and activities that are aligned to Common Core standards. We encourage you to browse by concept, grade level, or activity type, and assign independent practice as you see fit. Typically, each activity may be completed in 15 to 20 minutes or less. Your student or child will receive instant feedback to help them reach proficiency at their own pace.

To view all of the activities you’ve assigned, go to the ‘My Activities’ tab on your dashboard.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices6.png)

# Use the diagnostic
If you’d like a good starting point, we suggest having your student or child first complete one of our diagnostics to receive a personalized learning plan that you can assign to them based on their individual needs. Each assessment is 22 questions in length, and upon completion, you will have the option to assign your student or child up to eight weeks of activities catered to their unique needs. Under the ‘Assign Activities’ tab, click the ‘Entry Diagnostics’ card. You can choose from the Starter, Intermediate, Advanced, and ELL diagnostics.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices7.png)

After you’ve assigned one and your student or child has completed it, you can see their results by going to the ‘Student Reports’ tab on your dashboard and clicking ‘Diagnostics.’ On that page, click ‘Recommendations’ to view all the diagnostic-recommended independent activities that you can assign to your student or child.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/homeschoolbestpractices8.png)

# Try it out for yourself
We encourage parents to take a diagnostic themselves to get started. Maybe it has been a while since you've studied grammar explicitly, or perhaps you want to brush up on grammar principles. Either way, feel free to choose a topic that interests you, and show your student or child that learning is a lifelong process! As outlined in a previous step, you can browse all our content on the ‘Explore All Activities’ page and find ones that pique your interest. Play through some activities on your own to get a feel for them and determine which ones you would like to assign to your student or child.

By following these few easy steps, Quill can be fully integrated into your homeschool curriculum in no time. For even more resources, visit [**support.quill.org.**](https://support.quill.org/)

title: New Writing Skills Survey for AP Available Now
body:
In an effort to further support AP teachers in providing flexible learning opportunities for their students, the College Board® has worked with Quill.org to develop free new resources to help students practice targeted sentence construction skills in their writing. Quill.org is a non-profit organization that has developed entirely free online writing practice activities for students, focusing on foundational skills important for success in writing. Quill helps students practice sentence construction skills by using artificial intelligence to automatically grade sentence-level writing activities and provide students with personalized feedback.

To get started, students will complete a short, 17-item skills survey on a range of writing skills, and Quill will then provide you with a roster of personalized practice activities you can digitally assign to students who need further skill development. The focus areas include complex sentences, relative clauses, appositive phrases, participial phrases, compound-complex sentences, parallel structure, and advanced combining.

**How this works:**
* Teacher signs up for Quill (it’s free!) and assigns Quill’s Writing Skills Survey for AP
* Students take 30-minute skills survey
* Teacher accesses recommended practice activities to assign to students over the next 2-3 weeks - even having students practice just one skill is beneficial!
* Students should spend 10 minutes per activity over the next 2-3 weeks (note: there are about 5-6 activities per pack)

As a teacher, you’ll have the option to track which of your students are using Quill and the number of activities they complete.

For more information we encourage you to check out the Writing Skills Survey for AP here: [https://quill.org/AP](https://quill.org/AP)

These free resources will also be available next academic year and beyond, and may be especially useful for developing writers at the start of the school year

title: Tiny Tips for Teachers: Encourage Replay for Improved Recall
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-05-06_at_3.56.24_PM.png)
Are you familiar with our replay feature for students? Students can [replay any previously completed activity on Quill](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/3812794-what-does-the-student-dashboard-look-like) as often as they wish as long as it is still available on their student dashboard.

In some instances, you might feel students' being able to replay an activity is an excellent opportunity for students to work towards mastery of particular grammar concepts. In other cases, you may even be frustrated that your students continue to replay activities without remembering to move forward on their newly assigned activities.

Rest assured, replaying an activity is worthy of your students' time, and with some added guidance can help them improve their digital and paper writing exponentially.

### **Why Replay? Retrieval Practice Helps Understanding!**

When students replay an activity, they go through the entire exercise again with the questions in a slightly different order. The activity's questions order shuffles with each replay, so if students remember anything, it is the rule they are practicing and the feedback that helped them answer correctly.  You do not need to worry about students remembering the correct answers because if they do, this is a good thing! Our goal is to have what students learn and practice on Quill transfer into their authentic writing. We increase this likelihood with focused recall through replays.

Replaying activities is an excellent activity in actively recalling information learned, best known as **[retrieval practice](https://www.retrievalpractice.org/).**

Retrieval practice is a strategy in which learners call up knowledge from their memory bank. The focus on getting information out of our minds helps strengthen understanding of what we are retrieving. In the instances in which a student cannot successfully recall information, they would continue to practice until the recall of this material becomes smoother and smoother. If you want to learn more about retrieval practice (which you may already be doing in other areas of your instruction), you can find more about it over at [Cult of Pedagogy, where Jennifer Gonzales helpfully condenses the research backing this strategy](https://www.cultofpedagogy.com/retrieval-practice/).

### **Using Quill for Retrieval Practice**

**Tip #1 - Reward Improvement Over Finite Scores**

Use Quill replays as a place for students to earn "effort" credit for improvement. Rather than assigning a hard and fast grade for some of your power standards, consider a grading scale where for two or three grammar skills, the goal is to simply improve a score (and understanding of the grammar concept) over time.  Using the [Activity Summary report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work), you can see your students' number of attempts on an assignment, as well as their score on each attempt.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-05-06_at_4.02.56_PM.png)
Some of your Quill assigned activities may be graded on this improvement/effort scale. Some of your assignments will be assigned the raw percentage based on mastery. You have the flexibility to decide.

**Tip #2 - Help Students Space Their Replays**

As the name suggests, spacing is a learning strategy that encourages spacing out your practice strategically as opposed to only working on one type of skill and not returning to it.  Paired with retrieval practice, spacing out practice helps encode information into the long-term memory.

Helping students space out replays can be as simple as:

- During alternating months or week, only allow replays in certain activity packs or on certain concepts.
- Share a "practice calendar" with students on your teacher website or LMS (learning management system) such as Google Classroom.
- Only allow replays of one activity once every set number of days or weeks.
- Explain to students the value of spacing out their replay practice and encourage them to take ownership over the process.

**Tip #3 - Help Students Focus Their Replays**

Replaying an activity just to have something to do may not lead to marked improvement on a skill. Help students strategize their replaying of Quill activities by having them focus on only 2-3 activities over a duration of time. You can do this by:

- Having students replay only those activities that are orange (nearly proficient) or red (not yet proficient) until they have scored a green (proficient). Here at Quill, we like to call this "going for green!"
- Specifying which pack or which 2-3 activities of grammar concepts should be replayed. If your state, district, or school considers specific skills power skills, students can replay these more than other activities.

### **How Are Other Teachers Making this Work?**

- [Kaysi Adams Encourages Student Ownership](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/student-ownership--kaysi-adams-5th-grade-writing-teacher) - “I let students do the activities as many times as they want before the due date.”
- [Carla Byars "Quill and Chill"](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/carla-byars-teacher-story-) - “I ask my students to replay all activities until the puzzle piece is green,” she says. “When they don’t understand why they didn’t get it on green the first time they submit, I can help them with the concepts they’re struggling with.”
- [Jennifer Beasley Encourages Digital Agility](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/meeting-students-where-they-are--jennifer-beasley-8th-grade-ela-teacher) - “While my students don’t like to make mistakes, [Quill.org](http://quill.org/) helped them to realize that making mistakes is part of the learning process,” says Beasley, continuing, “They can go back and redo activities for mastery and more credit. They receive two [Quill.org](http://quill.org/) grades per quarter (one for the first four weeks; one for the second). I assigned activities ahead of time so students could work on them at their own pace.”

title: FAQ: New AP® Writing Skills Survey
body:
## **What is the AP® Writing Skills Survey?**

The [AP® Writing Skills Survey](https://quill.org/AP) is a survey with 17 questions on a range of writing skills. The questions ask students to combine sentences, sometimes with a direction to use a specific strategy, and sometimes without any direction (other than to combine).

## **What does the Survey assess?**

The Survey assesses students’ proficiency in constructing sentences with **relative clauses**, **appositive phrases**, **participial phrases**, and **parallel structure**, as well as their general ability to do **advanced sentence combining,** and to write **complex** and **compound-complex sentences.**

## **Who developed the AP® Writing Skills Survey?**

Quill.org worked with the [College Board](http://www.collegeboard.org)® to develop this Survey and the AP Writing Practice activity packs that will be recommended based on your students' performance.

## **Who is the Survey for?**

The Survey was designed for students in [Advanced Placement](https://apcentral.collegeboard.org/courses/ap-course-audit/explore-by-role/teachers)® courses. Please note, however, that students' performance on the Survey will only be recorded if it is assigned to them by their teacher.

## **How long does the Survey take?**

The Survey contains 17 questions and is designed to take about 30 minutes for students to complete.

## **How do I assign the Survey to my students?**

<a target='_blank' href='http://quill.org/AP' class='article-cta-primary'>
Click here to assign the Survey! </br>
<a href="http://quill.org/AP" target="_blank">

To find the Survey yourself on Quill.org, [go to our library of activities](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1303931-how-can-i-search-a-specific-topic-on-quill) and filter by Diagnostics. *Note*: Although the Survey is listed under Diagnostics, it has been developed as a customized tool based on [AP course](https://diagnostic.quill.org/#/play/diagnostic/-L_wPCxbrT6toCb1fnYR?anonymous=true) [](https://apcentral.collegeboard.org/courses)[frameworks](https://diagnostic.quill.org/#/play/diagnostic/-L_wPCxbrT6toCb1fnYR?anonymous=true). Therefore, the Survey can be used in lieu of a general Quill Diagnostic.

## **What happens after I assign the Survey and my students complete it?**

After you have assigned the Survey and your students have completed it, Quill will show you how your students performed and provide recommendations of personalized practice activities you can digitally assign to students who need further skill development. [This article](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589522-how-do-i-assign-diagnostic-recommendations) explains how to find and assign those recommendations.

## **What kind of activities will be recommended to my students after they take the AP® Writing Skills Survey?**

Depending on their performance, students will be recommended some or all of the following AP Writing Practice packs. The packs provide practice through [Quill Connect](https://www.quill.org/tools/connect), [Quill's sentence combining tool](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/-3). With the exception of the [AP Writing - Advanced Sentence Combining pack](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/142), the activities in each pack are scaffolded to build in complexity. Here are descriptions of the packs:

### AP® Writing Practice - **[Complex Sentences](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/139)**

Students practice constructing complex sentences using subordinating conjunctions, such as *even though, after, while*, and *because*. Students also practice identifying time order, opposition, and cause/effect relationships.

### AP® Writing Practice - **[Relative Clauses](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/140)**

Students begin by using a provided relative pronoun, then progress to choosing between *who, that,* or *which*.

### AP® Writing Practice - **[Appositive Phrases](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/143)**

Students practice describing nouns using appositive phrases at the beginning, middle, and end of sentences.

### AP® Writing Practice - **[Participial Phrases](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/144)**

Students practice constructing sentences with *-ing* and *-ed* participial phrases at the beginning, middle, or end.

### AP® Writing Practice - **[Parallel Structure](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/192)**

Students practice constructing sentences in parallel structure with correlative conjunctions like *either/or, neither/nor,* and *both/and*, and with subordinating conjunctions like *although, because,* and *when*. Students also practice constructing sentences with parallel clauses.

### AP® Writing Practice - **[Compound-Complex Sentences](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/141)**

Students practice constructing compound sentences with *and, or, but,* and *so.* Students also practice constructing complex sentences with subordinating conjunctions such as *even though, after, while,* and *because.* Finally, students practice constructing compound-complex sentences with coordinating and subordinating conjunctions. Students also practice identifying time order, opposition, and cause/effect relationships.

### AP® Writing Practice - **[Advanced Combining](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/142)**

Students apply their knowledge of multiple sentence structures to combine the sentences in the strongest way possible. Students practice constructing compound and complex sentences, using modifying phrases and clauses, and combining predicates.

## **Can students complete the AP Writing Practice packs independently?**

Yes! From anywhere and at any time! Again though, please note that recommendations of the AP Writing Packs are generated after students complete the AP Writing Skills Survey. Please also note that students' performance on the AP Writing Practice packs will only be recorded if they are assigned to them by their teacher.

## **How many activities are in each AP Writing Practice pack and how long will it take students to complete them?**

All of the above packs contain between 4 and 7 activities, each of which are designed to take between 10 and 15 minutes each.

The only exception is the [AP Writing - Advanced Combining pack](https://www.quill.org/assign/featured-activity-packs/142), which contains 15 activities. This pack contains more activities than the others as it was designed to serve as a large bank of activities for students who perform well on the Survey and don’t get a lot of recommendations. This way, you can still assign these students activities, which are quite challenging and will sustain them for a while. These are great for students who have had success with individual practice of strategies covered in the Survey, and would benefit from an opportunity to apply those strategies in combining activities without suggestions or direction.

*Teacher Tip:* When you select a recommended pack, you can [remove any](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1137376-can-i-remove-activities-or-assignments-from-my-activity-packs) [activities](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1258572-how-do-i-assign-only-some-activities-in-a-pack) [within it](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1137376-can-i-remove-activities-or-assignments-from-my-activity-packs). And once it's assigned, you can add activities to the pack as well.

## **What grade-level or reading level are the AP Activity Packs designed for?**

The focus in most of these activities is to build the target skill of the pack (appositives, relative clauses, etc.), so the vocabulary and reading level are intentionally designed to be accessible by all students.

*Teacher Tip*: You can preview and play through any pack and its activities to get a sense of whether it's appropriate for your students.

## **Will my students receive feedback as they work through the AP Writing Practice activity packs?**

Yes! In each recommended practice activity, Quill provides students with immediate feedback on their writing that they can use to revise their responses up to 5 times. Through these rounds of feedback and revision, students improve the clarity and precision of their writing.

## **Where can I track my students' completion of and performance on the AP Writing Practice packs?**

Quill has a variety of reports to help you track your students' performance and progress. In the [Activity Summary report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work), you can quickly see which activities your students have completed, along with color-coded icons indicating their proficiency with each activity. Quill has several other reports as well. [This Cheat Sheet](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_Reports_Cheat_Sheet_Updated04_08_20.pdf) shows you which report to go to for particular information, and [this video](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Getting_Started_-_Student_Data_Reports__Basic_.mp4) will walk you through interpreting and utilizing three of Quill's student data reports.

## **How many AP Writing Practice packs should I assign to my students?**

You can assign all the recommended practice at once, or you can pick and choose the ones that best fit your instructional and students’ needs. Since most of the AP Writing Practice packs contain between 4 and 7 activities, we suggest expecting students to complete about 1 pack a week. [This article](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1065187-how-can-i-assign-activities-in-a-specific-order) explains how you can use deadlines to help students pace themselves.

## **If my students have been using Quill for a while, will they encounter activities in the AP Writing Practice packs that they have completed before?**

The activities in the AP Writing Practice packs are curated from existing Quill activities. While your students may encounter an activity they have already completed, the AP Writing Practice packs have been customized to target the skills students need to write successfully at the AP level. Given the quantity and variety of activities available on Quill, chances are that the AP Writing Practice packs will include plenty of new activities, even for students who have been using Quill for a while.

## **Can I assign my students practice beyond the recommended AP Writing Practice packs?**

Yes! Quill offers [5 different tools](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1327607-what-are-each-of-the-different-quill-tools) with more than 600 writing, grammar, and proofreading activities designed to engage students in the writing process. [This article](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049944-how-do-i-assign-a-featured-activity-pack) will show you how to explore and assign Quill’s featured activity packs, and [this article](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049954-how-do-i-create-and-assign-a-new-activity-pack) will show you how to create a custom activity pack.

## **Do I need to create an account on Quill.org to assign the AP Writing Skills Survey?**

It is recommended that you and your students create free accounts on [Quill.org](http://quill.org). Creating an account will give you access to the Survey and its recommended practice. Creating an account also allows you to track your students’ progress and view data reports. You can create an account by visiting the [Quill sign-up page](https://www.quill.org/account/new).

If you do not want to create an account, you or your students can complete the Survey [here](https://diagnostic.quill.org/#/play/diagnostic/-L_wPCxbrT6toCb1fnYR?anonymous=true). However, **please note** that if you do not create an account, your students’ performance on the Survey will not be saved or shared with you, and you will not have access to the recommended skills practice. You will also not be able to track student progress or view data reports.

## **What if I still have questions?**

**[Teacher Center:](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center)** Browse additional resources and more information about how to use Quill.

**Quill Support:** Email [support@quill.org](mailto:support@quill.org) (Be sure to mention that you’re an AP teacher!)

**Quill Support Chat**: While you’re on Quill.org, you can use the chat bubble in the lower right side of your screen to connect with a member of the Quill support team. (Again, be sure to mention that you’re an AP teacher!)

**Quill Instructional Coach**: You can reach out directly to Sherry Lewkowicz, one of our Senior Instructional Coaches focused on Quill’s work with the College Board, at [sherry@quill.org](mailto:sherry@quill.org) (Again, be sure to mention that you’re an AP teacher!)

**Quill Phone Number**: (510) 671-0222

We are always happy to help!

*AP® is a registered trademark of the College Board.*

title: Tiny Tips for Teachers: Naming Packs to Signal Purpose
body:
We've all been the victim of poor file-naming at some time or another. You were logging on to your computer with moments to spare, frantically looking for the files associated with today's lessons, only to spend 10 minutes trying to hunt down that one document named Document87.doc or something equally obscure.

You finally get fed up enough to begin naming your files a little bit more consistently. Before long, your Google Drive or hard drive has a relatively easy to navigate and search organization set-up. Better file-naming saves you time, energy, and looks good. Mission accomplished!

Whether you have found that file organization sweet spot yet or not, our students likely experience a similar problem when they organize and when we miss opportunities to name things clearly for them. **How does this relate to naming activity packs in Quill?** The pack naming issue is the same as the file organization one, and we have some ideas to help you create a more streamlined experience for you and your students.

- Not sure what an activity pack is? Read this support article: [Creating & Assigning a New Activity Pack](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049954-how-do-i-create-and-assign-a-new-activity-pack)
- Have you taken a look at our [Featured Activity Packs](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049944-how-do-i-assign-a-featured-activity-pack)? The following tips will work for those activity packs as well.

### **Tip #1: Edit Activity Pack Names**

Quill suggests activity pack titles for you, but those titles can be changed to better suit your needs. To edit an activity pack name, [follow the steps outlined in this support article.](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1303290-how-do-i-change-the-name-of-an-activity-pack)

![Image showing that the edit name option underneath the activity pack name](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Untitled.png)

### **Tip #2: Adopt a Consistent Pack Naming System**

Adopting consistent activity pack naming allows for students to automatically understand the purpose or time for a specific activity pack.

**Types of Activity Pack Names:**

- Dates or Weeks
- Student Group, Whole Group, or Personalized Packs
- Part of Lesson Specific
- Unit Specific
- Concept Specific

**Stack Your Pack Names:**

To help further keep things consistent, always use the names you decide upon, and stack them when possible. For example, if I have an activity pack for a specific date *and* a particular unit, I would add both naming conventions to my pack title. Again, keeping this consistent helps students over time understand how to find packs.

- Week 5, Group A - Unit 2 Sentence Practice
- May 12-15 - Whole Group Bell-Ringers
- Personalized Playlist (Diagnostic Recs) - June

![Example of a teacher's activity naming on her dashboard](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/14_May_2020_-_Loom_Recording__1_.gif)

### **Tip #3: Communicate this Naming System & "Find on Page" Shortcut**

**Communicating the Activity Pack Name**

Once you have decided how you will name your activity packs, communicating it can be as simple as stating what pack students should work on for the day or week. You can do this on a learning management system such as  Schoology or Blackboard, as well as online classroom tools such as Google Classroom. The more you refer to activity packs in a particular way, the more students will be able to understand the logic behind your naming system.

![An example of a Quill activity pack being assigned manually in Google Classroom.](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Untitled__1_.png)


**Using "Find on Page" Shortcut Easily Locate Packs**

Using the "find on page" shortcut keys ctrl+f (PC) or cmd+F (Mac), quickly locate clear activity pack titles on the activities page! With clear activity pack titles, both you and your students can skip the step of scrolling for a particular pack title and instead jump right to that location on a page.

![By using the "find" shortcut, students and teachers can quickly locate packs that use a known naming system.](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/13_May_2020_-_Loom_Recording__1___1_.gif)

title: Using Quill with Students with IEPs
body:
At Quill, we understand that no two students are the same. We do not promote any kind of blanket implementation approach for our tools; instead, we tailor each of our learning plans to the needs of students based on their diagnostic performance.

Here are a few ways that these flexible and differentiated learning pathways can help you support your IEP students!


## **Individual Help at your Student’s Own Pace**

Using our 500+ independent practice activities,  students with IEPs can move at their own pace and get the most out of each activity. Our activities never time out, lock students out, or rush students, so students can learn and succeed on their own timelines. In addition to these features, here are a few tips to help students get the most out of their time on Quill.

### Tip #1: Encourage students use the built-in supports

On Quill, we provide students with both real-time feedback and hints as they work through their activities. If students feel stuck on a question, encourage them to slow down, scroll down, and take a look at the hint provided. Often, these hints model how to correctly combine the sentences.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020_05_05_at_2_26_15_PM__1_.png)

Quill also alerts students when they have made a spelling mistake. Encourage students to keep an eye out for bolded words after they submit, as bolding indicates that the word is misspelled.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-05-05_at_2.20.57_PM__1_.png)

### Tip #2: Take Advantage of Quill's Extensions

Quill is compatible with a [**number of outside extensions for students with modifications**](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1058670-free-extensions-for-students-with-modifications-iep-ell) that can aid students with typing, reading, and more as they work through their Quill activities.

### Tip #3: Keep an eye on student real-time feedback

Quill color codes feedback as students work through their activities. Walk around as students are working through their activities and assist students that are receiving large amounts of orange feedback.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-05-05_at_2.20.57_PM.png)


### Tip #4: Modify Student Workload or Activity Type

On Quill, you're able to modify both the number of activities in a pack and the types of activities in a pack. If the recommended workload for students feels too high, you can gradually release the recommended activities for students from the Diagnostic Recommendations page by unchecking the activities that you do not wish to assign yet. Don't worry—you won't lose the recommendations by doing so! When you come back to the page at a later date to assign the next cohort of activities, the previously assigned activities will be marked in green, and the remaining recommendations will be marked in black.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2020-05-05_at_2.33.17_PM.png)

If the number of activities in the recommended pack itself feels too high, or if there is a certain tool that does not meet the needs of your students, you can remove individual activities from packs from the "My Activities" tab.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Quill_org_Interactive_Writing_and_Grammar__1_.png)

### Tip #5: Encourage Oral Practice

Practicing Quill Connect activities, or pedagogically similar activities, out loud is a great way to help students understand how certain grammar concepts function.

You can use oral components to support students throughout the entire process of completing a Quill activity. To begin, you can record a model of you answering Quill questions or receiving and incorporating Quill feedback. Students can play it back whenever they need a reminder, and helps parents know how to reinforce skills as well.

Once students have completed an activity, or if students need support understanding the activity's function as they are working on it, have students practice the concept out loud.

 ***Try this model with your class:***

1. Students share their favorite sentence they wrote on Quill that day with their teacher.
2. Working together as a class (or one-on-one over a voice recording, if you're teaching remotely), have students practice combining their classmate's favorite sentences out loud with new conjunctions.

*Student's favorite sentence:* The bear hibernated because it was winter.

*Teacher-provided conjunction:* since

*New student sentence (orally)*: The bear hibernated since it was winter.

title: Tiny Tips for Teachers: Pacing the Assignment of Diagnostic Recommendations
body:
Many teachers use one of [Quill's diagnostic assessments](https://www.quill.org/teacher-center/quill-tools-overview-of-quills-5-diagnostics) to create personalized learning programs for their students. Quill recommends up to eight activity packs to each student based on their individual diagnostic results. The first time you visit the **[Diagnostic Recommendations](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1589522-how-do-i-assign-diagnostic-recommendations)** screen after students complete the assessment, you'll see each student's recommended activity packs both highlighted in blue *and* marked with a black check:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Diag_Rec_Screen.png)
From here, you have several options as to how you pace assigning the recommended activities to best support your students' progress and mastery.

### **Option #1: Assign All Recommendations and Let Students Pace Themselves**

From the **Diagnostic Recommendations** screen, you can choose to simply click "Assign Activity Packs," and all recommended packs will immediately be assigned to students and loaded into their dashboards (keeping in mind that the number of activities per pack can range from two to ten or more). Students can then work through their assignments at their own pace while receiving [targeted practice](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1049963-is-there-a-fixed-progression-of-activities-on-quill) to fill the writing skill gaps identified by the diagnostic. Self-pacing can be a powerful college-readiness experience for older students.

***Quick Tip:** You can also use Quill's [due date feature](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1065187-how-can-i-assign-activities-in-a-specific-order) to give students more deliberate guidance when self-pacing.*

### **Option #2: Stagger Release of Recommended Activity Packs**

You may decide that seeing up to eight activity packs at once in their dashboard could be overwhelming for your students, especially if they are still working on how to pace their independent practice time. Or you may be using Quill to support a particular unit or curricular sequence and want to time different concepts to align with planned lessons. You can use the **Diagnostic Recommendations** screen to only assign one activity pack to students at a time. This way, students can work on completing a pack aligned to a single concept and will not have the opportunity to skip around. To control the release of activity packs:

- First, click the "Uncheck All" option to remove the black checks from all highlighted activity pack boxes.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Uncheck_All.png)
- Then, manually check off the activity packs you'd like to assign immediately and click "Assign Activity Packs."
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Green_Checks.png)
- The assigned packs will be marked with a green check to indicate they are loaded into the students' dashboards. The other recommended packs will remain highlighted in blue, but will not be assigned as of yet. You can come back and check off more activity packs to assign when you and your students are ready.

***Quick Tip:** Use the [Activity Summary report](https://support.quill.org/en/articles/1140159-how-does-the-activity-summary-work) to track your students' progress live and determine when they are ready to move onto a new activity pack.*

### **Option #3: Adjust the Number of Activities per Recommended Pack**

Each activity pack is made up of Quill activities aligned to the pack's title concept. However, the number of activities in each pack differs (some packs have as low as two activities while others have more than ten). You also can adjust the number of activities in a recommended pack right after you assign it:

- In the "My Activities" tab on your Quill dashboard, scroll to the activity pack you have just assigned and would like to adjust. Then, click on the "x" next to any specific activity you would like to remove from the pack. Once it is removed from your dashboard, it will also be removed from the students' dashboards.
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Cap_Practice.png)

***Final Quick Tip:** Did you already assign all recommended activity packs but decide that you'd rather stagger their release? Not to worry, there's a quick fix for that! Just go to your "My Activities" page and click "Delete Activity Pack" under the packs you'd like to remove. The green checks on your Diagnostic Recommendations screen will be removed and reverted back to black-and-white checks. You can then assign these activity packs again at a later date. (Just note that if any students already started working on an activity in the deleted packs, their activity progress and score will be deleted as well).*
subtitle: Teachers have several options as to how to pace and organize the assignment of the activities recommended by the Quill Diagnostic.

title: Fast Company Selects Quill.org as one of the World’s Most Innovative Companies for 2018
body:
![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/fasco.png)

Quill.org is honored to be named one of Fast Company’s [**10 Most Innovative Companies in Education for 2018**](https://www.fastcompany.com/most-innovative-companies/2018/sectors/education). Quill was chosen by a panel of three dozen Fast Company editors, reporters, and contributors who reviewed more than 1,500 nonprofit and for-profit companies. “At a time marked by political and economic uncertainty,” said David Lidsky, the Deputy Editor at Fast Company, Quill.org’s “ability to rise to the top of the field is especially meaningful and inspiring.” He warmly welcomed Quill.org “to a dynamic, inspiring class of companies from around the world.”

Quill.org is a nonprofit educational technology startup dedicated to helping low-income students become great writers. Approximately 27 million students in the U.S. struggle with basic writing, one of the most important skills young people need to graduate high school, enroll and succeed in college and advance their careers. Quill is building free, open source tools to widely disseminate time-tested and research-validated writing strategies that support and enhance critical thinking. In 2016, Quill.org launched Quill Connect, a tool that uses machine learning to help teachers provide basic writing skills instruction in their classrooms. Quill’s algorithms automatically grade and serve feedback on writing, enabling students to revise their work and express their thoughts precisely in writing.

As a nonprofit organization, Quill.org is specifically focused on the writing needs of underserved students. 64% of the students who use Quill.org attend Title 1 eligible schools, and Quill.org has partnered with literacy experts and classrooms teachers to design materials tailored to the specific needs of their target population. Quill.org’s materials are completely free for students and teachers, and the nonprofit generates revenue by charging schools and districts to access analytics and obtain professional development around research-backed writing instruction.

Quill is now supporting more than 5,000 schools across the United States, with 700,000 students having written and received feedback on 70 million sentences. Within the next five years, Quill.org aims to help 10 million low-income students improve their writing and thinking skills. Quill.org is grateful for the funding of visionary supporters including the Heckscher Foundation for Children, AT&T Foundation, Louis Calder Foundation, Voqal Foundation, Edwin Gould Foundation, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, among others.

Learn more about [**Quill.org**](https://www.quill.org).

Quill.org is honored to be selected along with the following companies:

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/FastCompany_Image.png)

Press Contact

Peter Gault, Executive Director

hello@quill.org

title: Family Toolbox: Creating a Culture of Writing at Home
body:
Becoming a strong writer takes deliberate, repeated practice — just like the practice it takes to become a stellar athlete or accomplished musician. By dedicating time for regular practice of writing skills at home *and* encouraging your children to utilize these skills in their writing outside of Quill, you can help instill a positive and powerful culture of writing in your household.

### Extending Quill Practice Beyond the Screen

As children regularly use Quill's online activities to practice their grammar and sentence construction skills, they are setting important building blocks in place to improve the clarity and precision of their writing across all content areas and audiences. In order to make that transfer between skill practice and fluid writing, you can try incorporating one or more of the extension activities below into your child's home learning schedule.

- **Start a writing skill progress journal.** While working through Quill's activities, your child will be practicing many writing rules, skills, and concepts. Have your child keep a notebook tracking these concepts so that they can refer to this growing compendium of skills when writing assignments. One way to organize the notebook is to list a new skill or concept on each page. Then, your child can write 1-2 sample sentences highlighting the concept in use, along with any tips or tricks they've learned along the way.

    ![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Skill_Journal.png)

- **Celebrate strong sentences.** Quill's activities help students write precise sentences, often by incorporating specific parts of speech to help clarify the meaning behind an idea. When your child writes an exemplary sentence during a Quill activity and receives positive feedback, have them write that sentence on a Post-it and tack it onto a nearby board or wall spot. Soon, they'll have a growing collection of strong sentences to use as inspiration in future writing pieces!
- **Observe writers in action.** As your child is reading (for school or pleasure), ask them to observe how different writers use the skills and concepts they have been practicing on Quill. For example, if your child recently completed the Quill Connect activity "Adjectives in Lists," ask them to look for a list of three adjectives connected by commas in a text they're currently reading. When they find the concept in use, have them highlight or underline the sentence (or jot it on a Post-it, a different color than the strong sentence Post-its)!

### Sparking a Conversation About Writing

One of the key features of Quill is the real-time feedback students receive after writing a sentence. For example, a strong sentence will elicit positive reinforcement from Quill:

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Feedback_-_Positive.png)

However, sentences that need structural or mechanical improvement will receive specific feedback to help students make the appropriate corrections:

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Feedback_-_Structural.png)

You can use Quill's feedback to spark more in-depth conversations with your child about their writing. Having your child explain their word choices and narrate their editing process after receiving feedback is a powerful way to help them develop the important internal dialogue strong writers have as they construct precise sentences. Here are a few examples of conversation starters to try as your child works through a Quill activity:

- Wow, that's a great sentence! What did you do that made it so strong?
- Why do you think Quill told you to fix that part of your sentence? What are you going to write instead?
- Oh, it looks like Quill noticed you forgot a period at the end of your sentence. What's a way you can help yourself remember for next time?

You can also carry these conversations beyond Quill work time to help reinforce the transfer from skill practice to fluid, thoughtful writing. For example:

- In the chapter you read today for ELA, show me a sentence you think is really strong. What did the writer do to make that such a strong sentence?
- Can you show me a sentence in your Social Studies paragraph where you used a concept you practiced on Quill this week? How did using this concept make your sentence or paragraph better?

If you have any other ideas about ways to instill a positive culture of writing at home, please share them with us! You can reach us anytime at hello@quill.org to talk through the successes and challenges of working with your growing writers at home.

Help instill a positive culture of writing at home by extending your children's Quill practice beyond the screen.

title: How Quill Gives Feedback
body:
Here at Quill, we believe that offering feedback on student work is an essential part of the teaching process. Our feedback model, which has been recognized by several leading [**tech and education publications**](https://www.quill.org/press), is distinct among writing instruction tools because our software recognizes a wide range of errors and responds with instant, targeted feedback. Targeted feedback allows students to learn from their mistakes rather than simply memorize the right answer. Our software also shows students multiple correct answers when appropriate, which reinforces the idea that there may be several correct ways to write a sentence. Students can then decide which response they prefer and incorporate it into their writing.

In this article, we’re going to look underneath the hood at how Quill generates this immediate, targeted feedback for students.

## Instant Feedback

Quill’s feedback encourages a robust revision process. Correct student responses cannot contain grammatical errors of any kind regardless of the activity's grammar target. For example, if a student fails to add a punctuation mark at the end of a sentence but has done everything else correctly, he or she will be prompted, “*Check for missing punctuation.*” The student will move on to the next question once he or she rewrites the sentence with the correct punctuation included, or after providing several incorrect answers. Students can submit up to two responses per question on Quill Grammar and up to five responses per question on Quill Connect.

After the class completes an activity, the teacher can go to the [**Activity Analysis**](https://support.quill.org/data-and-reporting/how-do-i-read-the-activity-analysis) under the *Student Reports* tab to view the specific grammar concepts that students mastered or missed. This teaches students to incorporate a wide range of sentence construction strategies into their writing while allowing teachers to monitor student progress on key grammar skills.

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2018-07-12_at_12.02.23_PM.png)

## Clear Guidance

Quill strives to empower students to become independent writers. Our feedback is therefore designed to guide students along as they work out the correct answer for themselves. To this end, we avoid using overly technical jargon for grammar concepts and instead explain each grammar concept with simple and clear language that is easily understood by students at many levels. Our feedback also prompts students towards the correct answer by asking them to think about the structure and purpose of the sentence. In the example below, you can see what happens when a student forms a compound sentence using the joining word and instead of the more accurate joining word, *so.*

![](http://s3.amazonaws.com/quill-image-uploads/uploads/files/Screen_Shot_2018-07-12_at_12.34.52_PM.png)

​​
Notice that we do not use the technical term, “conjunction,” but instead use the simpler term“joining word” to explain the error. By suggesting that the joining word should show a causal relationship, we show students how to make their sentence even more precise. This is especially helpful in cases where students structure their sentence in a way which sounds correct, but would be awkward or incorrect in mature writing.

## Mastery-Based Grading

Another important feature of Quill’s feedback is its mastery-based grading system. With the Activity Analysis report, teachers can see the answers students submitted, the feedback they received, and the concepts they either mastered or missed for each activity. Students earn Proficient (green) for scoring between 80-100%, Nearly Proficient (yellow) for scoring between 60%-79%, and Needs More Practice (red) for scoring between 0%-59%. Our grading system gives students the chance to submit multiple incorrect responses before they are prompted to move on. For each incorrect submission, students are given more feedback that guides them towards the correct answer. Students never see their numerical grade; rather, they can see their color code based on how well they have mastered the concept.

## Advanced Error Detection

All of this is possible because of Quill’s advanced error detection system. Our content team works behind the scenes to ensure that each question is accurately graded with direct and relevant feedback. When grading questions, we begin by inputting all of the possible correct responses. This tells the algorithm how to recognize when a student submission does not match the optimal response, and algorithm will flag the submission as incorrect.

The algorithm can detect many kinds of errors, such as when the student includes a typo or forgets to capitalize the beginning of a sentence. Each type of error that the student misses is grouped together and assigned a concept tag, which corresponds with a particular grammar concept. Concept tags are used both to tell the computer what kind of feedback a student should receive and to track students’ mastery of specific grammar concepts across activities. The student will be provided with targeted feedback, and the teacher will see which grammatical concept the student missed.

For more information on Quill’s grading system, please see the following [**article.**](https://support.quill.org/data-and-reporting/how-does-grading-work)
